21-1099.title: Community and Social Service Specialists, All Other

21-2011.desc: Conduct religious worship and perform other spiritual functions associated with beliefs and practices of religious faith or denomination. Provide spiritual and moral guidance and assistance to members.
21-2011.title: Clergy

21-2021.desc: Coordinate or design programs and conduct outreach to promote the religious education or activities of a denominational group. May provide counseling, guidance, and leadership relative to marital, health, financial, and religious problems.
21-2021.ex: Religious Education Director, Youth Ministry Director
21-2021.title: Directors, Religious Activities and Education

21-2099.desc: All religious workers not listed separately.
21-2099.title: Religious Workers, All Other

23-1011.desc: Represent clients in criminal and civil litigation and other legal proceedings, draw up legal documents, or manage or advise clients on legal transactions. May specialize in a single area or may practice broadly in many areas of law.
23-1011.title: Lawyers

23-1012.desc: Assist judges in court or by conducting research or preparing legal documents.
23-1012.title: Judicial Law Clerks

23-1020._label: Judges, Magistrates, and Other Judicial Workers

23-1021.desc: Conduct hearings to recommend or make decisions on claims concerning government programs or other government-related matters. Determine liability, sanctions, or penalties, or recommend the acceptance or rejection of claims or settlements.
23-1021.ex: Appeals Examiner, Justice of The Peace, Traffic Court Referee
23-1021.title: Administrative Law Judges, Adjudicators, and Hearing Officers

23-1022.desc: Facilitate negotiation and conflict resolution through dialogue. Resolve conflicts outside of the court system by mutual consent of parties involved.
23-1022.ex: Alternative Dispute Resolution Coordinator, Mediation Commissioner, Ombudsman
23-1022.title: Arbitrators, Mediators, and Conciliators

23-1023.desc: Arbitrate, advise, adjudicate, or administer justice in a court of law. May sentence defendant in criminal cases according to government statutes or sentencing guidelines. May determine liability of defendant in civil cases. May perform wedding ceremonies.
23-1023.ex: Circuit Court Judge, Justice, Tribal Judge
23-1023.title: Judges, Magistrate Judges, and Magistrates

23-2011.desc: Assist lawyers by investigating facts, preparing legal documents, or researching legal precedent. Conduct research to support a legal proceeding, to formulate a defense, or to initiate legal action.
23-2011.title: Paralegals and Legal Assistants

23-2093.desc: Search real estate records, examine titles, or summarize pertinent legal or insurance documents or details for a variety of purposes. May compile lists of mortgages, contracts, and other instruments pertaining to titles by searching public and private records for law firms, real estate agencies, or title insurance companies.
23-2093.ex: Escrow Officer, Lien Searcher, Title Officer
23-2093.title: Title Examiners, Abstractors, and Searchers

23-2099.desc: All legal support workers not listed separately.
23-2099.title: Legal Support Workers, All Other

25-1011.desc: Teach courses in business administration and management, such as accounting, finance, human resources, labor and industrial relations, marketing, and operations research. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1011.ex: Accounting Professor, Finance Professor, Marketing Professor
25-1011.title: Business Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1020._label: Math and Computer Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1021.desc: Teach courses in computer science. May specialize in a field of computer science, such as the design and function of computers or operations and research analysis. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1021.ex: Computer Information Systems Professor, Information Technology Professor, Java Programming Professor
25-1021.title: Computer Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1022.desc: Teach courses pertaining to mathematical concepts, statistics, and actuarial science and to the application of original and standardized mathematical techniques in solving specific problems and situations. 25-1022.ex: Actuarial Science Professor, Calculus Professor, Statistics Professor
25-1022.title: Mathematical Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1031.desc: Teach courses in architecture and architectural design, such as architectural environmental design, interior architecture/design, and landscape architecture. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1031.ex: Architectural Design Professor, Landscape Architecture Professor
25-1031.title: Architecture Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1032.desc: Teach courses pertaining to the application of physical laws and principles of engineering for the development of machines, materials, instruments, processes, and services. Includes teachers of subjects such as chemical, civil, electrical, industrial, mechanical, mineral, and petroleum engineering. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1032.ex: Aeronautical Engineering Professor, Civil Engineering Professor, Electrical Engineering Professor, Marine Engineering Professor
25-1032.title: Engineering Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1041.desc: Teach courses in the agricultural sciences. Includes teachers of agronomy, dairy sciences, fisheries management, horticultural sciences, poultry sciences, range management, and agricultural soil conservation. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1041.ex: Agronomy Professor, Aquaculture and Fisheries Professor, Farm Management Professor
25-1041.title: Agricultural Sciences Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1042.desc: Teach courses in biological sciences. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1042.ex: Bacteriology Professor, Biochemistry Professor, Botany Professor
25-1042.title: Biological Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1043.desc: Teach courses in forestry and conservation science. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1043.ex: Forest Ecology Professor, Timber Management Professor, Wildlife Conservation Professor
25-1043.title: Forestry and Conservation Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1051.desc: Teach courses in the physical sciences, except chemistry and physics. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching, and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1051.ex: Climatology Professor, Geology Professor, Oceanography Professor
25-1051.title: Atmospheric, Earth, Marine, and Space Sciences Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1052.desc: Teach courses pertaining to the chemical and physical properties and compositional changes of substances. Work may include providing instruction in the methods of qualitative and quantitative chemical analysis. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching, and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1052.ex: Inorganic Chemistry Professor, Organic Chemistry Professor, Physical Chemistry Professor
25-1052.title: Chemistry Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1053.desc: Teach courses in environmental science. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1053.title: Environmental Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1054.desc: Teach courses pertaining to the laws of matter and energy. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1054.ex: Astrophysics Professor, Ballistics Professor, Hydrodynamics Professor, Thermodynamics Professor
25-1054.title: Physics Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1061.desc: Teach courses in anthropology or archeology. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.

25-1061.title: Anthropology and Archeology Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1062.desc: Teach courses pertaining to the culture and development of an area, an ethnic group, or any other group, such as Latin American studies, women's studies, or urban affairs. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1062.ex: Ethnology Professor, Latin American Studies Professor, Women's Studies Professor
25-1062.title: Area, Ethnic, and Cultural Studies Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1063.desc: Teach courses in economics. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.

25-1063.title: Economics Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1064.desc: Teach courses in geography. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.

25-1064.title: Geography Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1065.desc: Teach courses in political science, international affairs, and international relations. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1065.ex: Government Professor, International Relations Professor, Public Policy Professor
25-1065.title: Political Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1066.desc: Teach courses in psychology, such as child, clinical, and developmental psychology, and psychological counseling. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1066.ex: Child Development Professor, Educational Psychology Professor, Industrial/Organizational Psychology Professor
25-1066.title: Psychology Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1067.desc: Teach courses in sociology. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.

25-1069.desc: All postsecondary social sciences teachers not listed separately.
25-1069.ex: Survey Research Professor, Urban Planning Professor
25-1069.title: Social Sciences Teachers, Postsecondary, All Other

25-1071.desc: Teach courses in health specialties, in fields such as dentistry, laboratory technology, medicine, pharmacy, public health, therapy, and veterinary medicine.
25-1071.ex: Nutrition Professor, Pharmacology Professor, Public Health Professor
25-1071.title: Health Specialties Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1072.desc: Demonstrate and teach patient care in classroom and clinical units to nursing students. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1072.ex: Advanced Nursing Professor, Clinical Nursing Professor, Registered Nursing Professor
25-1072.title: Nursing Instructors and Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1080._label: Education and Library Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1081.desc: Teach courses pertaining to education, such as counseling, curriculum, guidance, instruction, teacher education, and teaching English as a second language. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1081.ex: Primary Education Professor, Special Education Professor
25-1081.title: Education Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1082.desc: Teach courses in library science. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1082.ex: Library and Information Science Professor, Medical Records Library Professor
25-1082.title: Library Science Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1110._label: Law, Criminal Justice, and Social Work Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1112.title: Law Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1113.title: Social Work Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1120._label: Arts, Communications, History, and Humanities Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1121.desc: Teach courses in drama, music, and the arts including fine and applied art, such as painting and sculpture, or design and crafts. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1121.ex: Ballet Professor, Photography Professor, Piano Professor
25-1121.title: Art, Drama, and Music Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1122.desc: Teach courses in communications, such as organizational communications, public relations, radio/television broadcasting, and journalism. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1122.title: Communications Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1123.desc: Teach courses in English language and literature, including linguistics and comparative literature. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1123.ex: Contemporary English Literature Professor, Creative Writing English Professor, Etymology Professor
25-1123.title: English Language and Literature Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1124.desc: Teach languages and literature courses in languages other than English. Includes teachers of American Sign Language (ASL). Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1124.ex: Chinese Language Professor, Russian Language Professor, Spanish Literature Professor
25-1124.title: Foreign Language and Literature Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1125.desc: Teach courses in human history and historiography. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1125.ex: African History Professor, American History Professor, Jewish History Professor, Russian History Professor
25-1125.title: History Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1126.desc: Teach courses in philosophy, religion, and theology. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1126.ex: Divinity Professor, Eastern Philosophy Professor, Theology Professor
25-1126.title: Philosophy and Religion Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1192.desc: Teach courses in childcare, family relations, finance, nutrition, and related subjects pertaining to home management. Includes both teachers primarily engaged in teaching and those who do a combination of teaching and research.
25-1192.ex: Family and Consumer Sciences Professor, Family Resource Management Professor, Home Economics Professor
25-1192.title: Family and Consumer Sciences Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1193.ex: Kinesiology Professor, Leisure Studies Professor, Physical Education (PE) Professor
25-1193.title: Recreation and Fitness Studies Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1194.desc: Teach vocational courses intended to provide occupational training below the baccalaureate level in subjects such as construction, mechanics/repair, manufacturing, transportation, or cosmetology, primarily to students who have graduated from or left high school. Teaching takes place in public or private schools whose primary business is academic or vocational education. Flight instructors are included with "Aircraft Pilots and Flight Engineers" (53-2010).
25-1194.ex: Automotive Technology Instructor, Cosmetology Instructor, HVAC Instructor, Mechanical Maintenance Instructor
25-1194.title: Career/Technical Education Teachers, Postsecondary

25-1199.desc: All postsecondary teachers not listed separately.
25-1199.title: Postsecondary Teachers, All Other

25-2011.desc: Instruct preschool-aged students, following curricula or lesson plans, in activities designed to promote social, physical, and intellectual growth.
25-2011.ex: Home-based Preschool Teacher, Nursery School Teacher, Preschool Head Start Teacher
25-2011.title: Preschool Teachers, Except Special Education

25-2012.desc: Teach academic and social skills to kindergarten students.
25-2012.title: Kindergarten Teachers, Except Special Education

25-2021.ex: 4th Grade Math Teacher, Elementary School Music Teacher
25-2021.title: Elementary School Teachers, Except Special Education

25-2022.desc: Teach one or more subjects to students at the middle, intermediate, or junior high school level.
25-2022.ex: Intermediate School Social Studies Teacher, Junior High School Teacher, Middle School Science Teacher
25-2022.title: Middle School Teachers, Except Special and Career/Technical Education

25-2023.desc: Teach occupational, vocational, career, or technical subjects to students at the middle, intermediate, or junior high school level.

25-2032.desc: Teach occupational, vocational, career, or technical subjects to students at the secondary school level.
25-2032.ex: High School Auto Repair Teacher, High School Cosmetology Teacher
25-2032.title: Career/Technical Education Teachers, Secondary School

25-2051.desc: Teach academic, social, and life skills to preschool-aged students with learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. 25-2051.title: Special Education Teachers, Preschool

25-2055.desc: Teach academic, social, and life skills to kindergarten students with learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. Includes teachers who specialize and work with students who are blind or have visual impairments; students who are deaf or have hearing impairments; and students with intellectual disabilities.
25-2055.title: Special Education Teachers, Kindergarten

25-2056.desc: Teach academic, social, and life skills to elementary school students with learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. Includes teachers who specialize and work with students who are blind or have visual impairments; students who are deaf or have hearing impairments; and students with intellectual disabilities.
25-2056.title: Special Education Teachers, Elementary School

25-2057.desc: Teach academic, social, and life skills to middle school students with learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. Includes teachers who specialize and work with students who are blind or have visual impairments; students who are deaf or have hearing impairments; and students with intellectual disabilities.
25-2057.ex: Junior High School Special Education Teacher, Middle School Special Education Teacher
25-2057.title: Special Education Teachers, Middle School

25-2058.desc: Teach academic, social, and life skills to secondary school students with learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. Includes teachers who specialize and work with students who are blind or have visual impairments; students who are deaf or have hearing impairments; and students with intellectual disabilities.
25-2058.ex: High School Special Education Resource Teacher
25-2058.title: Special Education Teachers, Secondary School

25-2059.desc: All special education teachers not listed separately.
25-2059.ex: Special Education Teacher for Adults with Disabilities
25-2059.title: Special Education Teachers, All Other

25-3010._label: Adult Basic Education, Adult Secondary Education, and English as a Second Language Instructors

25-3011.desc: Teach or instruct out-of-school youths and adults in basic education, literacy, or English as a Second Language classes, or in classes for earning a high school equivalency credential.
25-3011.ex: Adult Education Teacher, Adult English as a Second Language (ESL) Teacher, Adult Literacy Instructor, General Educational Development (GEDï¿½) Teacher
25-3011.title: Adult Basic Education, Adult Secondary Education, and English as a Second Language Instructors

25-3021.desc: Teach or instruct individuals or groups for the primary purpose of self-enrichment or recreation, rather than for an occupational objective, educational attainment, competition, or fitness. Flight instructors are included with "Aircraft Pilots and Flight Engineers" (53-2010).
25-3021.ex: Citizenship Teacher, Knitting Instructor, Recreational Activities Instructor
25-3021.title: Self-Enrichment Teachers

25-3031.desc: Teach students on a short-term basis as a temporary replacement for a regular classroom teacher, typically using the regular teacher's lesson plan.
25-3031.ex: Elementary School Substitute Teacher, English Substitute Teacher
25-3031.title: Substitute Teachers, Short-Term

25-3041.ex: Algebra Tutor, Reading Tutor, Spanish Tutor, Standardized Test Tutor
25-3041.title: Tutors

25-3099.desc: All teachers and instructors not listed separately.
25-3099.title: Teachers and Instructors, All Other

25-4011.desc: Appraise, edit, and direct safekeeping of permanent records and historically valuable documents. Participate in research activities based on archival materials.
25-4011.ex: Film Archivist, Historical Records Administrator, Reference Archivist
25-4011.title: Archivists

25-4012.desc: Administer collections, such as artwork, collectibles, historic items, or scientific specimens of museums or other institutions. May conduct instructional, research, or public service activities of institution.
25-4012.ex: Herbarium Curator, Photography and Prints Curator
25-4012.title: Curators

25-4013.desc: Restore, maintain, or prepare objects in museum collections for storage, research, or exhibit. May work with specimens such as fossils, skeletal parts, or botanicals; or artifacts, textiles, or art. May identify and record objects or install and arrange them in exhibits. 25-4013.ex: Ethnographic Materials Conservator, Museum Exhibit Technician, Textile Conservator
25-4013.title: Museum Technicians and Conservators

25-4022.desc: Administer and maintain libraries or collections of information, for public or private access through reference or borrowing. Work in a variety of settings, such as educational institutions, museums, and corporations, and with various types of informational materials, such as books, periodicals, recordings, films, and databases. Tasks may include acquiring, cataloging, and circulating library materials, and user services such as locating and organizing information, providing instruction on how to access information, and setting up and operating a library's media equipment.
25-4022.ex: Library Media Specialist, Multimedia Services Coordinator, Music Librarian, School Librarian
25-4022.title: Librarians and Media Collections Specialists

25-4031.desc: Assist librarians by helping readers in the use of library catalogs, databases, and indexes to locate books and other materials; and by answering questions that require only brief consultation of standard reference. Compile records; sort and shelve books or other media; remove or repair damaged books or other media; register patrons; and check materials in and out of the circulation process. Replace materials in shelving area (stacks) or files. Includes bookmobile drivers who assist with providing services in mobile libraries.
25-4031.ex: Library Acquisitions Technician, Library Circulation Technician
25-4031.title: Library Technicians

25-9000._label: Other Educational Instruction and Library Occupations

25-9021.desc: Instruct and advise individuals and families engaged in agriculture, agricultural-related processes, or home management activities. May instruct on either agricultural issues such as agricultural processes and techniques, pest management, and food safety, or on home management issues such as budgeting, nutrition, and child development.
25-9021.ex: Agricultural Extension Educator, Family Resource Management Specialist, Feed Management Advisor
25-9021.title: Farm and Home Management Educators

25-9031.title: Instructional Coordinators

25-9042.title: Teaching Assistants, Preschool, Elementary, Middle, and Secondary School, Except Special Education

25-9043.desc: Assist a preschool, elementary, middle, or secondary school teacher to provide academic, social, or life skills to students who have learning, emotional, or physical disabilities. 25-9044.desc: Assist faculty or other instructional staff in postsecondary institutions by performing instructional support activities, such as developing teaching materials, leading discussion groups, preparing and giving examinations, and grading examinations or papers. 25-9044.ex: Assistant Instructor, College Biology Teaching Assistant, University Teaching Assistant
25-9044.title: Teaching Assistants, Postsecondary

25-9049.desc: All teaching assistants not listed separately.

25-9049.title: Teaching Assistants, All Other

25-9099.title: Educational Instruction and Library Workers, All Other

27-0000._label: Arts, Design, Entertainment, Sports, and Media Occupations

27-1011.desc: Formulate design concepts and presentation approaches for visual productions and media, such as print, broadcasting, video, and film. Direct workers engaged in artwork or layout design.
27-1011.title: Art Directors

27-1012.desc: Create or reproduce handmade objects for sale and exhibition using a variety of techniques, such as welding, weaving, pottery, and needlecraft.
27-1012.ex: Hand Potter, Metal Crafts Artist, Quilter
27-1012.title: Craft Artists

27-1013.desc: Create original artwork using any of a wide variety of media and techniques.
27-1013.ex: Ice Sculptor, Political Cartoonist, Scientific Illustrator, Sketch Artist
27-1013.title: Fine Artists, Including Painters, Sculptors, and Illustrators

27-1014.desc: Create special effects or animations using film, video, computers, or other electronic tools and media for use in products, such as computer games, movies, music videos, and commercials.
27-1014.title: Special Effects Artists and Animators

27-1019.desc: All artists and related workers not listed separately.
27-1019.title: Artists and Related Workers, All Other

27-1021.desc: Design and develop manufactured products, such as cars, home appliances, and children's toys. Combine artistic talent with research on product use, marketing, and materials to create the most functional and appealing product design.
27-1021.title: Commercial and Industrial Designers

27-1022.desc: Design clothing and accessories. Create original designs or adapt fashion trends.
27-1022.ex: Costume Designer, Custom Furrier, Dress Designer
27-1022.title: Fashion Designers

27-1023.desc: Design, cut, and arrange live, dried, or artificial flowers and foliage.
27-1023.title: Floral Designers

27-1024.desc: Design or create graphics to meet specific commercial or promotional needs, such as packaging, displays, or logos. May use a variety of mediums to achieve artistic or decorative effects.
27-1024.title: Graphic Designers

27-1025.desc: Plan, design, and furnish the internal space of rooms or buildings. Design interior environments or create physical layouts that are practical, aesthetic, and conducive to the intended purposes. May specialize in a particular field, style, or phase of interior design.
27-1025.ex: Home Lighting Adviser, Interior Decorator, Kitchen Designer
27-1025.title: Interior Designers

27-1026.desc: Plan and erect commercial displays, such as those in windows and interiors of retail stores and at trade exhibitions.
27-1026.ex: Display Artist, Mannequin Decorator, Window Decorator
27-1026.title: Merchandise Displayers and Window Trimmers

27-1027.desc: Design special exhibits and sets for film, video, television, and theater productions. May study scripts, confer with directors, and conduct research to determine appropriate architectural styles.
27-1027.title: Set and Exhibit Designers

27-2000._label: Entertainers and Performers, Sports and Related Workers

27-2011.desc: Play parts in stage, television, radio, video, or film productions, or other settings for entertainment, information, or instruction. Interpret serious or comic role by speech, gesture, and body movement to entertain or inform audience. May dance and sing.
27-2011.title: Actors

27-2012.desc: Produce or direct stage, television, radio, video, or film productions for entertainment, information, or instruction. Responsible for creative decisions, such as interpretation of script, choice of actors or guests, set design, sound, special effects, and choreography.
27-2012.ex: Casting Director, Independent Film Maker, Stage Manager
27-2012.title: Producers and Directors

27-2020._label: Athletes, Coaches, Umpires, and Related Workers

27-2021.ex: Professional Football Player, Professional Jockey, Professional Race Car Driver
27-2021.title: Athletes and Sports Competitors

27-2022.desc: Instruct or coach groups or individuals in the fundamentals of sports for the primary purpose of competition. Demonstrate techniques and methods of participation. May evaluate athletes' strengths and weaknesses as possible recruits or to improve the athletes' technique to prepare them for competition. Those required to hold teaching certifications should be reported in the appropriate teaching category.
27-2022.ex: Baseball Scout, Boxing Coach, Football Coach
27-2022.title: Coaches and Scouts

27-2023.desc: Officiate at competitive athletic or sporting events. Detect infractions of rules and decide penalties according to established regulations. Includes all sporting officials, referees, and competition judges.
27-2023.ex: Athletic Events Scorer, Paddock Judge, Race Starter
27-2023.title: Umpires, Referees, and Other Sports Officials

27-2031.desc: Perform dances. May perform on stage, for broadcasting, or for video recording.
27-2031.title: Dancers

27-2032.desc: Create new dance routines. Rehearse performance of routines. May direct and stage presentations.
27-2032.title: Choreographers

27-2041.desc: Conduct, direct, plan, and lead instrumental or vocal performances by musical artists or groups, such as orchestras, bands, choirs, and glee clubs; or create original works of music.
27-2041.title: Music Directors and Composers

27-2042.desc: Play one or more musical instruments or sing. May perform on stage, for broadcasting, or for sound or video recording.
27-2042.title: Musicians and Singers

27-2090._label: Miscellaneous Entertainers and Performers, Sports and Related Workers

27-2091.desc: Play prerecorded music for live audiences at venues or events such as clubs, parties, or wedding receptions. May use techniques such as mixing, cutting, or sampling to manipulate recordings. May also perform as emcee (master of ceremonies). Radio disc jockeys are included in "Broadcast Announcers and Radio Disc Jockeys" (27-3011).
27-2091.title: Disc Jockeys, Except Radio

27-2099.desc: All entertainers and performers, sports and related workers not listed separately.
27-2099.ex: Clown, Comedian, Magician, Professional Poker Player
27-2099.title: Entertainers and Performers, Sports and Related Workers, All Other

27-3010._label: Broadcast Announcers and Radio Disc Jockeys

27-3011.desc: Speak or read from scripted materials, such as news reports or commercial messages, on radio, television, or other communications media. May play and queue music, announce artist or title of performance, identify station, or interview guests.
27-3011.ex: Game Show Host, Radio Disc Jockey, Talk Show Host
27-3011.title: Broadcast Announcers and Radio Disc Jockeys

27-3023.desc: Narrate or write news stories, reviews, or commentary for print, broadcast, or other communications media such as newspapers, magazines, radio, or television. May collect and analyze information through interview, investigation, or observation.
27-3023.ex: Columnist, Correspondent, Film Critic, News Anchor
27-3023.title: News Analysts, Reporters, and Journalists

27-3031.desc: Promote or create an intended public image for individuals, groups, or organizations. May write or select material for release to various communications media. May specialize in using social media.
27-3031.title: Public Relations Specialists

27-3041.desc: Plan, coordinate, revise, or edit written material. May review proposals and drafts for possible publication.
27-3041.ex: Advertising Editor, Copy Editor, Technical Editor
27-3041.title: Editors

27-3042.desc: Write technical materials, such as equipment manuals, appendices, or operating and maintenance instructions. May assist in layout work.
27-3042.title: Technical Writers

27-3043.desc: Originate and prepare written material, such as scripts, stories, advertisements, and other material.
27-3043.ex: Advertising Copy Writer, Playwright, Television Writer
27-3043.title: Writers and Authors

27-3091.desc: Interpret oral or sign language, or translate written text from one language into another.
27-3091.ex: American Sign Language Interpreter, Court Interpreter, Diplomatic Interpreter
27-3091.title: Interpreters and Translators

27-3092.desc: Use verbatim methods and equipment to capture, store, retrieve, and transcribe pretrial and trial proceedings or other information. Includes stenocaptioners who operate computerized stenographic captioning equipment to provide captions of live or prerecorded broadcasts for hearing-impaired viewers.
27-3092.ex: Court Stenographer, Court Transcriber, Deposition Reporter, Realtime Captioner
27-3092.title: Court Reporters and Simultaneous Captioners

27-3099.desc: All media and communication workers not listed separately.
27-3099.title: Media and Communication Workers, All Other

27-4011.desc: Set up, maintain, and dismantle audio and video equipment, such as microphones, sound speakers, connecting wires and cables, sound and mixing boards, video cameras, video monitors and servers, and related electronic equipment for live or recorded events, such as concerts, meetings, conventions, presentations, podcasts, news conferences, and sporting events.
27-4011.ex: Video Control Operator, Video Production Assistant
27-4011.title: Audio and Video Technicians

27-4012.desc: Set up, operate, and maintain the electronic equipment used to acquire, edit, and transmit audio and video for radio or television programs. Control and adjust incoming and outgoing broadcast signals to regulate sound volume, signal strength, and signal clarity. Operate satellite, microwave, or other transmitter equipment to broadcast radio or television programs.
27-4012.title: Broadcast Technicians

27-4014.desc: Assemble and operate equipment to record, synchronize, mix, edit, or reproduce sound, including music, voices, or sound effects, for theater, video, film, television, podcasts, sporting events, and other productions.
27-4014.ex: Audio Recording Engineer, Sound Editor, Sound Effects Technician
27-4014.title: Sound Engineering Technicians

27-4015.desc: Set up, maintain, and dismantle light fixtures, lighting control devices, and the associated lighting electrical and rigging equipment used for photography, television, film, video, and live productions. May focus or operate light fixtures, or attach color filters or other lighting accessories.
27-4015.title: Lighting Technicians

27-4021.desc: Photograph people, landscapes, merchandise, or other subjects. May use lighting equipment to enhance a subject's appearance. May use editing software to produce finished images and prints. Includes commercial and industrial photographers, scientific photographers, and photojournalists.
27-4021.ex: Aerial Photographer, Medical Photographer, Portrait Photographer
27-4021.title: Photographers

27-4030._label: Television, Video, and Film Camera Operators and Editors

27-4031.desc: Operate television, video, or film camera to record images or scenes for television, video, or film productions.
27-4031.title: Camera Operators, Television, Video, and Film

27-4032.desc: Edit moving images on film, video, or other media. May work with a producer or director to organize images for final production. May edit or synchronize soundtracks with images.
27-4032.ex: Cue Selector, Film Editor, Television News Video Editor
27-4032.title: Film and Video Editors

27-4090._label: Miscellaneous Media and Communication Equipment Workers

27-4099.desc: All media and communication equipment workers not listed separately.
27-4099.title: Media and Communication Equipment Workers, All Other

29-1011.desc: Assess, treat, and care for patients by manipulation of spine and musculoskeletal system. May provide spinal adjustment or address sacral or pelvic misalignment.
29-1011.title: Chiropractors

29-1021.desc: Examine, diagnose, and treat diseases, injuries, and malformations of teeth and gums. May treat diseases of nerve, pulp, and other dental tissues affecting oral hygiene and retention of teeth. May fit dental appliances or provide preventive care.
29-1021.title: Dentists, General

29-1022.desc: Perform surgery and related procedures on the hard and soft tissues of the oral and maxillofacial regions to treat diseases, injuries, or defects. May diagnose problems of the oral and maxillofacial regions. May perform surgery to improve function or appearance.
29-1022.title: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons

29-1023.desc: Examine, diagnose, and treat dental malocclusions and oral cavity anomalies. Design and fabricate appliances to realign teeth and jaws to produce and maintain normal function and to improve appearance.
29-1023.ex: Dentofacial Orthopedics Dentist, Invisible Braces Orthodontist, Pediatric Orthodontist
29-1023.title: Orthodontists

29-1024.desc: Diagnose, treat, rehabilitate, design, and fit prostheses that maintain oral function, health, and appearance for patients with clinical conditions associated with teeth, oral and maxillofacial tissues, or the jaw.
29-1024.title: Prosthodontists

29-1031.desc: Plan and conduct food service or nutritional programs to assist in the promotion of health and control of disease. May supervise activities of a department providing quantity food services, counsel individuals, or conduct nutritional research.
29-1031.ex: Clinical Dietitian, Pediatric Dietician, Public Health Nutritionist
29-1031.title: Dietitians and Nutritionists

29-1041.desc: Diagnose, manage, and treat conditions and diseases of the human eye and visual system. Examine eyes and visual system, diagnose problems or impairments, prescribe corrective lenses, and provide treatment. May prescribe therapeutic drugs to treat specific eye conditions. Ophthalmologists are included in "Ophthalmologists, Except Pediatric" (29-1241).
29-1041.title: Optometrists

29-1051.desc: Dispense drugs prescribed by physicians and other health practitioners and provide information to patients about medications and their use. May advise physicians and other health practitioners on the selection, dosage, interactions, and side effects of medications.
29-1051.title: Pharmacists

29-1071.desc: Provide healthcare services typically performed by a physician, under the supervision of a physician. Conduct complete physicals, provide treatment, and counsel patients. May, in some cases, prescribe medication. Must graduate from an accredited educational program for physician assistants.
29-1071.ex: Anesthesiologist Assistant, Family Practice Physician Assistant
29-1071.title: Physician Assistants

29-1081.desc: Diagnose and treat diseases and deformities of the human foot.
29-1081.title: Podiatrists

29-1122.desc: Assess, plan, and organize rehabilitative programs that help build or restore vocational, homemaking, and daily living skills, as well as general independence, to persons with disabilities or developmental delays. Use therapeutic techniques, adapt the individual's environment, teach skills, and modify specific tasks that present barriers to the individual.
29-1122.title: Occupational Therapists

29-1123.desc: Assess, plan, organize, and participate in rehabilitative programs that improve mobility, relieve pain, increase strength, and improve or correct disabling conditions resulting from disease or injury.
29-1123.ex: Geriatric Physical Therapist, Physiotherapist, Pulmonary Physical Therapist
29-1123.title: Physical Therapists

29-1124.desc: Provide radiation therapy to patients as prescribed by a radiation oncologist according to established practices and standards. Duties may include reviewing prescription and diagnosis; acting as liaison with physician and supportive care personnel; preparing equipment, such as immobilization, treatment, and protection devices; and maintaining records, reports, and files. May assist in dosimetry procedures and tumor localization.
29-1124.title: Radiation Therapists

29-1125.desc: Plan, direct, or coordinate medically-approved recreation programs for patients in hospitals, nursing homes, or other institutions. Activities include sports, trips, dramatics, social activities, and crafts. May assess a patient condition and recommend appropriate recreational activity.
29-1125.ex: Certified Recreational Therapist, Drama Therapist, Therapeutic Recreation Specialist
29-1125.title: Recreational Therapists

29-1126.desc: Assess, treat, and care for patients with breathing disorders. Assume primary responsibility for all respiratory care modalities, including the supervision of respiratory therapy technicians. Initiate and conduct therapeutic procedures; maintain patient records; and select, assemble, check, and operate equipment.
29-1126.ex: Inhalation Therapist, Oxygen Therapist, Registered Respiratory Therapist
29-1126.title: Respiratory Therapists

29-1127.desc: Assess and treat persons with speech, language, voice, and fluency disorders. May select alternative communication systems and teach their use. May perform research related to speech and language problems.
29-1127.ex: Public School Speech Therapist, Speech Clinician, Speech Therapist
29-1127.title: Speech-Language Pathologists

29-1128.desc: Assess, plan, or implement fitness programs that include exercise or physical activities such as those designed to improve cardiorespiratory function, body composition, muscular strength, muscular endurance, or flexibility.
29-1128.ex: Applied Exercise Physiologist, Clinical Exercise Physiologist, Kinesiotherapist
29-1128.title: Exercise Physiologists

29-1131.desc: Diagnose, treat, or research diseases and injuries of animals. Includes veterinarians who conduct research and development, inspect livestock, or care for pets and companion animals.
29-1131.ex: Animal Surgeon, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Veterinary Cardiologist, Veterinary Medicine Scientist, Veterinary Radiologist, Wildlife Veterinarian
29-1131.title: Veterinarians

29-1141.desc: Assess patient health problems and needs, develop and implement nursing care plans, and maintain medical records. Administer nursing care to ill, injured, convalescent, or disabled patients. May advise patients on health maintenance and disease prevention or provide case management. Licensing or registration required. Includes Clinical Nurse Specialists.
29-1141.ex: Coronary Care Unit Nurse, Hospice Registered Nurse, Psychiatric Nurse
29-1141.title: Registered Nurses

29-1151.desc: Administer anesthesia, monitor patient's vital signs, and oversee patient recovery from anesthesia. May assist anesthesiologists, surgeons, other physicians, or dentists. Must be registered nurses who have specialized graduate education.
29-1151.title: Nurse Anesthetists

29-1161.desc: Diagnose and coordinate all aspects of the birthing process, either independently or as part of a healthcare team. May provide well-woman gynecological care. Must have specialized, graduate nursing education.
29-1161.title: Nurse Midwives

29-1171.desc: Diagnose and treat acute, episodic, or chronic illness, independently or as part of a healthcare team. May focus on health promotion and disease prevention. May order, perform, or interpret diagnostic tests such as lab work and x rays. May prescribe medication. Must be registered nurses who have specialized graduate education.
29-1171.ex: Cardiology Nurse Practitioner, Family Practice Nurse Practitioner, Gerontological Nurse Practitioner
29-1171.title: Nurse Practitioners

29-1181.desc: Assess and treat persons with hearing and related disorders. May fit hearing aids and provide auditory training. May perform research related to hearing problems.
29-1181.title: Audiologists

29-1211.desc: Administer anesthetics and analgesics for pain management prior to, during, or after surgery.
29-1211.title: Anesthesiologists

29-1212.desc: Diagnose, treat, manage, and prevent diseases or conditions of the cardiovascular system. May further subspecialize in interventional procedures (e.g., balloon angioplasty and stent placement), echocardiography, or electrophysiology.
29-1212.title: Cardiologists

29-1213.desc: Diagnose and treat diseases relating to the skin, hair, and nails. May perform both medical and dermatological surgery functions.
29-1213.title: Dermatologists

29-1214.desc: Make immediate medical decisions and act to prevent death or further disability. Provide immediate recognition, evaluation, care, stabilization, and disposition of patients. May direct emergency medical staff in an emergency department.
29-1214.ex: Critical Care Physician, Disaster Medicine Physician
29-1214.title: Emergency Medicine Physicians

29-1215.desc: Diagnose, treat, and provide preventive care to individuals and families across the lifespan. May refer patients to specialists when needed for further diagnosis or treatment.
29-1215.title: Family Medicine Physicians

29-1216.desc: Diagnose and provide nonsurgical treatment for a wide range of diseases and injuries of internal organ systems. Provide care mainly for adults and adolescents, and are based primarily in an outpatient care setting.
29-1216.ex: General Internist, Internal Medicine Physician, Internist
29-1216.title: General Internal Medicine Physicians

29-1217.desc: Diagnose, manage, and treat disorders and diseases of the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves, with a primarily nonsurgical focus.
29-1217.ex: Clinical Neuromuscular Pathologist, Epileptologist, Headache Specialist
29-1217.title: Neurologists

29-1218.desc: Provide medical care related to pregnancy or childbirth. Diagnose, treat, and help prevent diseases of women, particularly those affecting the reproductive system. May also provide general care to women. May perform both medical and gynecological surgery functions.
29-1218.ex: Gynecological Oncologist, Maternal-Fetal Medicine Physician, OB Specialist, OB/GYN
29-1218.title: Obstetricians and Gynecologists

29-1221.desc: Diagnose, treat, and help prevent diseases and injuries in children. May refer patients to specialists for further diagnosis or treatment, as needed.
29-1221.ex: Internal Medicine Pediatrician, Paediatrician, Pediatric Cardiologist, Pediatrist, Primary Care Pediatrician
29-1221.title: Pediatricians, General

29-1222.desc: Diagnose diseases and conduct lab tests using organs, body tissues, and fluids. Includes medical examiners.
29-1222.title: Physicians, Pathologists

29-1223.desc: Diagnose, treat, and help prevent mental disorders.
29-1223.ex: Addiction Psychiatrist, Forensic Psychiatrist, Geriatric Psychiatrist, Neuropsychiatrist
29-1223.title: Psychiatrists

29-1224.desc: Diagnose and treat diseases and injuries using medical imaging techniques, such as x rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), nuclear medicine, and ultrasounds. May perform minimally invasive medical procedures and tests.
29-1224.title: Radiologists

29-1241.desc: Diagnose and perform surgery to treat and help prevent disorders and diseases of the eye. May also provide vision services for treatment including glasses and contacts.
29-1241.ex: Cornea and External Disease Physician, Viteroretinal Disease Physician
29-1241.title: Ophthalmologists, Except Pediatric

29-1242.desc: Diagnose and perform surgery to treat and prevent rheumatic and other diseases in the musculoskeletal system.
29-1242.ex: Joint Preservationist, Orthopedic Sports Medicine Physician
29-1242.title: Orthopedic Surgeons, Except Pediatric

29-1243.desc: Diagnose and perform surgery to treat fetal abnormalities and birth defects, diseases, and injuries in fetuses, premature and newborn infants, children, and adolescents. Includes all pediatric surgical specialties and subspecialties.
29-1243.title: Pediatric Surgeons

29-1249.ex: Neurological Surgeon, Otolaryngologist, Thoracic Surgeon, Urologist
29-1249.title: Surgeons, All Other

29-1290._label: Miscellaneous Healthcare Diagnosing or Treating Practitioners

29-1291.desc: Diagnose, treat, and prevent disorders by stimulating specific acupuncture points within the body using acupuncture needles. May also use cups, nutritional supplements, therapeutic massage, acupressure, and other alternative health therapies.
29-1291.title: Acupuncturists

29-1292.desc: Administer oral hygiene care to patients. Assess patient oral hygiene problems or needs and maintain health records. Advise patients on oral health maintenance and disease prevention. May provide advanced care such as providing fluoride treatment or administering topical anesthesia.
29-1292.title: Dental Hygienists

29-1299.desc: All healthcare diagnosing or treating practitioners not listed separately.
29-1299.title: Healthcare Diagnosing or Treating Practitioners, All Other

29-2011.desc: Perform complex medical laboratory tests for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. May train or supervise staff.
29-2011.ex: Blood Bank Laboratory Technologist, Cytogenetic Technologist, Immunohematologist
29-2011.title: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists

29-2012.desc: Perform routine medical laboratory tests for the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. May work under the supervision of a medical technologist.
29-2012.ex: Histology Technician, Pathology Technician, Serology Technician
29-2012.title: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technicians

29-2031.desc: Conduct tests on pulmonary or cardiovascular systems of patients for diagnostic, therapeutic, or research purposes. May conduct or assist in electrocardiograms, cardiac catheterizations, pulmonary functions, lung capacity, and similar tests.
29-2031.title: Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians

29-2032.desc: Produce ultrasonic recordings of internal organs for use by physicians. Includes vascular technologists.
29-2032.ex: Echocardiographer, Registered Diagnostic Medical Sonographer, Ultrasound Technologist
29-2032.title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers

29-2033.desc: Prepare, administer, and measure radioactive isotopes in therapeutic, diagnostic, and tracer studies using a variety of radioisotope equipment. Prepare stock solutions of radioactive materials and calculate doses to be administered by radiologists. Subject patients to radiation. Execute blood volume, red cell survival, and fat absorption studies following standard laboratory techniques.
29-2033.ex: Certified Nuclear Medicine Technologist, Nuclear Cardiology Technologist, Radioisotope Technologist
29-2033.title: Nuclear Medicine Technologists

29-2034.desc: Take x-rays and CAT scans or administer nonradioactive materials into patient's bloodstream for diagnostic or research purposes. Includes radiologic technologists and technicians who specialize in other scanning modalities.
29-2034.ex: Computed Tomography (CT) Scanner Operator, X-Ray Technician
29-2034.title: Radiologic Technologists and Technicians

29-2035.desc: Operate Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scanners. Monitor patient safety and comfort, and view images of area being scanned to ensure quality of pictures. May administer gadolinium contrast dosage intravenously. May interview patient, explain MRI procedures, and position patient on examining table. May enter into the computer data such as patient history, anatomical area to be scanned, orientation specified, and position of entry.
29-2035.ex: Computed Tomography/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CT/MRI) Technologist, MRI Technologist
29-2035.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Technologists

29-2036.desc: Generate radiation treatment plans, develop radiation dose calculations, communicate and supervise the treatment plan implementation, and consult with members of radiation oncology team.
29-2036.ex: Certified Medical Dosimetrist, Qualified Medical Dosimetrist
29-2036.title: Medical Dosimetrists

29-2042.desc: Assess injuries and illnesses and administer basic emergency medical care. May transport injured or sick persons to medical facilities.
29-2042.title: Emergency Medical Technicians

29-2043.desc: Administer basic or advanced emergency medical care and assess injuries and illnesses. May administer medication intravenously, use equipment such as EKGs, or administer advanced life support to sick or injured individuals.
29-2043.title: Paramedics

29-2050._label: Health Practitioner Support Technologists and Technicians

29-2051.desc: Assist in the provision of food service and nutritional programs, under the supervision of a dietitian. May plan and produce meals based on established guidelines, teach principles of food and nutrition, or counsel individuals.
29-2051.title: Dietetic Technicians

29-2052.desc: Prepare medications under the direction of a pharmacist. May measure, mix, count out, label, and record amounts and dosages of medications according to prescription orders.
29-2052.title: Pharmacy Technicians

29-2053.desc: Care for individuals with mental or emotional conditions or disabilities, following the instructions of physicians or other health practitioners. Monitor patients' physical and emotional well-being and report to medical staff. May participate in rehabilitation and treatment programs, help with personal hygiene, and administer oral or injectable medications.
29-2053.ex: Behavioral Health Technician, Mental Health Technician
29-2053.title: Psychiatric Technicians

29-2055.desc: Assist in operations, under the supervision of surgeons, registered nurses, or other surgical personnel. May help set up operating room, prepare and transport patients for surgery, adjust lights and equipment, pass instruments and other supplies to surgeons and surgeons' assistants, hold retractors, cut sutures, and help count sponges, needles, supplies, and instruments.
29-2055.ex: Certified Surgical Technologist, OR Tech, Surgical Scrub Technologist
29-2055.title: Surgical Technologists

29-2056.desc: Perform medical tests in a laboratory environment for use in the treatment and diagnosis of diseases in animals. Prepare vaccines and serums for prevention of diseases. Prepare tissue samples, take blood samples, and execute laboratory tests, such as urinalysis and blood counts. Clean and sterilize instruments and materials and maintain equipment and machines. May assist a veterinarian during surgery.
29-2056.ex: Veterinary Laboratory Technician, Veterinary Surgery Technologist, Veterinary X-Ray Operator
29-2056.title: Veterinary Technologists and Technicians

29-2057.desc: Assist ophthalmologists by performing ophthalmic clinical functions. May administer eye exams, administer eye medications, and instruct the patient in care and use of corrective lenses.
29-2057.title: Ophthalmic Medical Technicians

29-2060._label: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses

29-2061.desc: Care for ill, injured, or convalescing patients or persons with disabilities in hospitals, nursing homes, clinics, private homes, group homes, and similar institutions. May work under the supervision of a registered nurse. Licensing required.
29-2061.ex: LPN, LVN, Pediatric Licensed Practical Nurse
29-2061.title: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses

29-2072.desc: Compile, process, and maintain medical records of hospital and clinic patients in a manner consistent with medical, administrative, ethical, legal, and regulatory requirements of the healthcare system. Classify medical and healthcare concepts, including diagnosis, procedures, medical services, and equipment, into the healthcare industry's numerical coding system. Includes medical coders.
29-2072.ex: Health Information Coder, Medical Bill Coder
29-2072.title: Medical Records Specialists

29-2081.desc: Design, measure, fit, and adapt lenses and frames for client according to written optical prescription or specification. Assist client with inserting, removing, and caring for contact lenses. Assist client with selecting frames. Measure customer for size of eyeglasses and coordinate frames with facial and eye measurements and optical prescription. Prepare work order for optical laboratory containing instructions for grinding and mounting lenses in frames. Verify exactness of finished lens spectacles. Adjust frame and lens position to fit client. May shape or reshape frames. Includes contact lens opticians.
29-2081.title: Opticians, Dispensing

29-2091.desc: Design, measure, fit, and adapt orthopedic braces, appliances or prostheses, such as limbs or facial parts for patients with disabling conditions.
29-2091.ex: Artificial Limb Fitter, Certified Orthotic Fitter, Pedorthist
29-2091.title: Orthotists and Prosthetists

29-2092.desc: Select and fit hearing aids for customers. Administer and interpret tests of hearing. Assess hearing instrument efficacy. Take ear impressions and prepare, design, and modify ear molds.
29-2092.ex: Hearing Aid Fitter, Hearing Aid Technician, Hearing Instrument Specialist
29-2092.title: Hearing Aid Specialists

29-2099.desc: All health technologists and technicians not listed separately.
29-2099.ex: Dialysis Technician, Electroencephalogram (EEG) Technologist, Electroneurodiagnostic Technologist, Polysomnograph Tech
29-2099.title: Health Technologists and Technicians, All Other

29-9000._label: Other Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Occupations

29-9020._label: Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars

29-9021.desc: Apply knowledge of healthcare and information systems to assist in the design, development, and continued modification and analysis of computerized healthcare systems. Abstract, collect, and analyze treatment and followup information of patients. May educate staff and assist in problem solving to promote the implementation of the healthcare information system. May design, develop, test, and implement databases with complete history, diagnosis, treatment, and health status to help monitor diseases.
29-9021.ex: Cancer Registrar, Health Informatics Specialist, Health Information Analyst
29-9021.title: Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars

29-9090._label: Miscellaneous Health Practitioners and Technical Workers

29-9091.desc: Evaluate and treat musculoskeletal injuries or illnesses. Provide preventive, therapeutic, emergency, and rehabilitative care.
29-9091.title: Athletic Trainers

29-9092.desc: Assess individual or family risk for a variety of inherited conditions, such as genetic disorders and birth defects. Provide information to other healthcare providers or to individuals and families concerned with the risk of inherited conditions. Advise individuals and families to support informed decisionmaking and coping methods for those at risk. May help conduct research related to genetic conditions or genetic counseling.
29-9092.ex: Chromosomal Disorders Counselor, Mitochondrial Disorders Counselor, Prenatal Genetic Counselor
29-9092.title: Genetic Counselors

29-9093.desc: Assist in operations, under the supervision of surgeons. May, in accordance with state laws, help surgeons to make incisions and close surgical sites, manipulate or remove tissues, implant surgical devices or drains, suction the surgical site, place catheters, clamp or cauterize vessels or tissue, and apply dressings to surgical site.
29-9093.title: Surgical Assistants

29-9099.desc: All healthcare practitioners and technical workers not listed separately.
29-9099.title: Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Workers, All Other

31-1100._label: Home Health and Personal Care Aides; and Nursing Assistants, Orderlies, and Psychiatric Aides

31-1120._label: Home Health and Personal Care Aides

31-1121.desc: Monitor the health status of an individual with disabilities or illness, and address their health-related needs, such as changing bandages, dressing wounds, or administering medication. Work is performed under the direction of offsite or intermittent onsite licensed nursing staff. Provide assistance with routine healthcare tasks or activities of daily living, such as feeding, bathing, toileting, or ambulation. May also help with tasks such as preparing meals, doing light housekeeping, and doing laundry depending on the patient's abilities.
31-1121.ex: Home Health Attendant, Home Hospice Aide
31-1121.title: Home Health Aides

31-1122.desc: Provide personalized assistance to individuals with disabilities or illness who require help with personal care and activities of daily living support (e.g., feeding, bathing, dressing, grooming, toileting, and ambulation). May also provide help with tasks such as preparing meals, doing light housekeeping, and doing laundry. Work is performed in various settings depending on the needs of the care recipient and may include locations such as their home, place of work, out in the community, or at a daytime nonresidential facility.
31-1122.ex: Blind Escort, Elderly Companion, Geriatric Personal Care Aide
31-1122.title: Personal Care Aides

31-1130._label: Nursing Assistants, Orderlies, and Psychiatric Aides

31-1131.desc: Provide or assist with basic care or support under the direction of onsite licensed nursing staff. Perform duties such as monitoring of health status, feeding, bathing, dressing, grooming, toileting, or ambulation of patients in a health or nursing facility. May include medication administration and other health-related tasks. Includes nursing care attendants, nursing aides, and nursing attendants.
31-1131.ex: Certified Nurse Aide, Certified Nursing Assistant, Nursing Care Attendant
31-1131.title: Nursing Assistants

31-1132.desc: Transport patients to areas such as operating rooms or x-ray rooms using wheelchairs, stretchers, or moveable beds. May maintain stocks of supplies or clean and transport equipment. Psychiatric orderlies are included in "Psychiatric Aides" (31-1133).
31-1132.ex: Hospital Orderly, Medical Orderly, Surgical Orderly
31-1132.title: Orderlies

31-1133.desc: Assist mentally impaired or emotionally disturbed patients, working under direction of nursing and medical staff. May assist with daily living activities, lead patients in educational and recreational activities, or accompany patients to and from examinations and treatments. May restrain violent patients. Includes psychiatric orderlies.
31-1133.ex: Mental Health Orderly, Psychiatric Nursing Aide, Psychiatric Technician Assistant
31-1133.title: Psychiatric Aides

31-2000._label: Occupational Therapy and Physical Therapist Assistants and Aides

31-2011.desc: Assist occupational therapists in providing occupational therapy treatments and procedures. May, in accordance with state laws, assist in development of treatment plans, carry out routine functions, direct activity programs, and document the progress of treatments. Generally requires formal training.
31-2011.ex: Certified Occupational Therapy Assistant, Licensed Occupational Therapy Assistant
31-2011.title: Occupational Therapy Assistants

31-2012.desc: Under close supervision of an occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant, perform only delegated, selected, or routine tasks in specific situations. These duties include preparing patient and treatment room.
31-2012.ex: Occupational Rehabilitation Aide, Occupational Therapist Aide
31-2012.title: Occupational Therapy Aides

31-2021.desc: Assist physical therapists in providing physical therapy treatments and procedures. May, in accordance with state laws, assist in the development of treatment plans, carry out routine functions, document the progress of treatment, and modify specific treatments in accordance with patient status and within the scope of treatment plans established by a physical therapist. Generally requires formal training.
31-2021.ex: Licensed Physical Therapist Assistant, Physiotherapy Assistant
31-2021.title: Physical Therapist Assistants

31-2022.desc: Under close supervision of a physical therapist or physical therapy assistant, perform only delegated, selected, or routine tasks in specific situations. These duties include preparing the patient and the treatment area.
31-2022.ex: Clinical Rehabilitation Aide, Physical Therapy Aide
31-2022.title: Physical Therapist Aides

31-9011.desc: Perform therapeutic massages of soft tissues and joints. May assist in the assessment of range of motion and muscle strength, or propose client therapy plans.
31-9011.ex: Deep Tissue Massage Therapist, Licensed Massage Therapist, Swedish Masseuse
31-9011.title: Massage Therapists

31-9091.desc: Perform limited clinical duties under the direction of a dentist. Clinical duties may include equipment preparation and sterilization, preparing patients for treatment, assisting the dentist during treatment, and providing patients with instructions for oral healthcare procedures. May perform administrative duties such as scheduling appointments, maintaining medical records, billing, and coding information for insurance purposes.
31-9091.title: Dental Assistants

31-9092.desc: Perform administrative and certain clinical duties under the direction of a physician. Administrative duties may include scheduling appointments, maintaining medical records, billing, and coding information for insurance purposes. Clinical duties may include taking and recording vital signs and medical histories, preparing patients for examination, drawing blood, and administering medications as directed by physician.
31-9092.ex: Chiropractic Assistant, Morgue Attendant, Orthopedic Cast Specialist
31-9092.title: Medical Assistants

31-9093.desc: Prepare, sterilize, install, or clean laboratory or healthcare equipment. May perform routine laboratory tasks and operate or inspect equipment.
31-9093.ex: Central Sterile Supply Technician, Sterilization Specialist
31-9093.title: Medical Equipment Preparers

31-9094.desc: Transcribe medical reports recorded by physicians and other healthcare practitioners using various electronic devices, covering office visits, emergency room visits, diagnostic imaging studies, operations, chart reviews, and final summaries. Transcribe dictated reports and translate abbreviations into fully understandable form. Edit as necessary and return reports in either printed or electronic form for review and signature, or correction.
31-9094.ex: Medical Stenographer, Medical Transcriber, Pathology Transcriptionist
31-9094.title: Medical Transcriptionists

31-9095.desc: Record drugs delivered to the pharmacy, store incoming merchandise, and inform the supervisor of stock needs. May operate cash register and accept prescriptions for filling.
31-9095.ex: Pharmacist Assistant, Pharmacy Clerk, Prescription Clerk
31-9095.title: Pharmacy Aides

31-9096.desc: Feed, water, and examine pets and other nonfarm animals for signs of illness, disease, or injury in laboratories and animal hospitals and clinics. Clean and disinfect cages and work areas, and sterilize laboratory and surgical equipment. May provide routine postoperative care, administer medication orally or topically, or prepare samples for laboratory examination under the supervision of veterinary or laboratory animal technologists or technicians, veterinarians, or scientists.
31-9096.title: Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers

31-9097.desc: Draw blood for tests, transfusions, donations, or research. May explain the procedure to patients and assist in the recovery of patients with adverse reactions.
31-9097.title: Phlebotomists

31-9099.desc: All healthcare support workers not listed separately.
31-9099.title: Healthcare Support Workers, All Other

33-1010._label: First-Line Supervisors of Law Enforcement Workers

33-1011.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of correctional officers and jailers.
33-1011.title: First-Line Supervisors of Correctional Officers

33-1012.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of members of police force.
33-1012.ex: Commanding Officer Homicide Squad, Detective Lieutenant, Police Lieutenant, Traffic Sergeant
33-1012.title: First-Line Supervisors of Police and Detectives

33-1020._label: First-Line Supervisors of Firefighting and Prevention Workers

33-1021.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in firefighting and fire prevention and control.
33-1021.ex: Fire Lieutenant, Municipal Fire Fighting and Prevention Supervisor, Supervising Fire Marshal
33-1021.title: First-Line Supervisors of Firefighting and Prevention Workers

33-1090._label: Miscellaneous First-Line Supervisors, Protective Service Workers

33-1091.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of security workers and security guards.
33-1091.ex: Loss Prevention Supervisor, Security Guard Supervisor, TSA Screener Supervisor
33-1091.title: First-Line Supervisors of Security Workers

33-1099.desc: All protective service supervisors not listed separately above.
33-1099.title: First-Line Supervisors of Protective Service Workers, All Other

33-2011.desc: Control and extinguish fires or respond to emergency situations where life, property, or the environment is at risk. Duties may include fire prevention, emergency medical service, hazardous material response, search and rescue, and disaster assistance.
33-2011.ex: Fire Engine Pump Operator, Forest Firefighter, Smoke Jumper
33-2011.title: Firefighters

33-2021.desc: Inspect buildings to detect fire hazards and enforce local ordinances and state laws, or investigate and gather facts to determine cause of fires and explosions.
33-2021.ex: Certified Vehicle Fire Investigator, Fire Hazard Inspector, Fire Prevention Inspector
33-2021.title: Fire Inspectors and Investigators

33-2022.desc: Enforce fire regulations, inspect forest for fire hazards, and recommend forest fire prevention or control measures. May report forest fires and weather conditions.
33-2022.ex: Environmental Protection Fire Control Officer, Forest Fire Control Officer, Wildfire Prevention Specialist
33-2022.title: Forest Fire Inspectors and Prevention Specialists

33-3011.desc: Maintain order in courts of law.
33-3011.ex: Court Bailiff, Court Security Officer, Deputy Bailiff
33-3011.title: Bailiffs

33-3012.desc: Guard inmates in penal or rehabilitative institutions in accordance with established regulations and procedures. May guard prisoners in transit between jail, courtroom, prison, or other point. Includes deputy sheriffs and police who spend the majority of their time guarding prisoners in correctional institutions.
33-3012.ex: Certified Detention Deputy, Juvenile Corrections Officer, Prison Guard
33-3012.title: Correctional Officers and Jailers

33-3021.desc: Conduct investigations related to suspected violations of federal, state, or local laws to prevent or solve crimes.
33-3021.ex: Deputy United States Marshal, Homicide Detective, Narcotics Investigator
33-3021.title: Detectives and Criminal Investigators

33-3031.desc: Patrol assigned area to prevent fish and game law violations. Investigate reports of damage to crops or property by wildlife. Compile biological data.
33-3031.ex: Conservation Enforcement Officer, Wildlife and Game Protector, Wildlife Officer
33-3031.title: Fish and Game Wardens

33-3041.desc: Patrol assigned area, such as public parking lot or city streets to issue tickets to overtime parking violators and illegally parked vehicles.
33-3041.title: Parking Enforcement Workers

33-3051.desc: Maintain order and protect life and property by enforcing local, tribal, state, or federal laws and ordinances. Perform a combination of the following duties: patrol a specific area; direct traffic; issue traffic summonses; investigate accidents; apprehend and arrest suspects, or serve legal processes of courts. Includes police officers working at educational institutions.
33-3051.ex: Border Patrol Officer, Campus Police Officer, Motorcycle Police, Park Police, State Trooper
33-3051.title: Police and Sheriff’s Patrol Officers

33-3052.desc: Protect and police railroad and transit property, employees, or passengers.
33-3052.ex: Railroad Detective, Track Patrol, Transit Authority Police
33-3052.title: Transit and Railroad Police

33-9011.desc: Handle animals for the purpose of investigations of mistreatment, or control of abandoned, dangerous, or unattended animals.
33-9011.ex: Animal Control Officer, Animal Warden, Dog Catcher, Humane Officer
33-9011.title: Animal Control Workers

33-9021.desc: Gather, analyze, compile, and report information regarding individuals or organizations to clients, or detect occurrences of unlawful acts or infractions of rules in private establishment.
33-9021.ex: Private Eye, Skip Tracer, Store Detective
33-9021.title: Private Detectives and Investigators

33-9030._label: Security Guards and Gambling Surveillance Officers

33-9031.desc: Observe gambling operation for irregular activities such as cheating or theft by either employees or patrons. Investigate potential threats to gambling assets such as money, chips, and gambling equipment. Act as oversight and security agent for management and customers.
33-9031.ex: Casino Investigator, Casino Surveillance Officer, Gambling Monitor
33-9031.title: Gambling Surveillance Officers and Gambling Investigators

33-9032.desc: Guard, patrol, or monitor premises to prevent theft, violence, or infractions of rules. May operate x-ray and metal detector equipment.
33-9032.title: Security Guards

33-9091.desc: Guide or control vehicular or pedestrian traffic at such places as streets, schools, railroad crossings, or construction sites.
33-9091.ex: Construction Site Crossing Guard, School Traffic Guard
33-9091.title: Crossing Guards and Flaggers

33-9092.desc: Monitor recreational areas, such as pools, beaches, or ski slopes, to provide assistance and protection to participants.
33-9092.ex: Beach Lifeguard, Outdoor Emergency Care Technician
33-9092.title: Lifeguards, Ski Patrol, and Other Recreational Protective Service Workers

33-9093.desc: Conduct screening of passengers, baggage, or cargo to ensure compliance with Transportation Security Administration (TSA) regulations. May operate basic security equipment such as x-ray machines and hand wands at screening checkpoints.
33-9093.ex: Airport Baggage Screener, Airport Security Screener, Transportation Security Administration (TSA) Screener, Transportation Security Officer
33-9093.title: Transportation Security Screeners

33-9094.desc: Maintain order among students on a school bus. Duties include helping students safely board and exit and communicating behavioral problems. May perform pretrip and posttrip inspections and prepare for and assist in emergency evacuations.
33-9094.title: School Bus Monitors

33-9099.desc: All protective service workers not listed separately.
33-9099.title: Protective Service Workers, All Other

35-0000._label: Food Preparation and Serving Related Occupations

35-1000._label: Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers

35-1010._label: Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers

35-1011.desc: Direct and may participate in the preparation, seasoning, and cooking of salads, soups, fish, meats, vegetables, desserts, or other foods. May plan and price menu items, order supplies, and keep records and accounts.
35-1011.ex: Executive Chef, Pastry Chef, Sous Chef
35-1011.title: Chefs and Head Cooks

35-1012.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in preparing and serving food.
35-1012.ex: Banquet Supervisor, Bar Manager, Kitchen Supervisor
35-1012.title: First-Line Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers

35-2011.desc: Prepare and cook food in a fast food restaurant with a limited menu. Duties of these cooks are limited to preparation of a few basic items and normally involve operating large-volume single-purpose cooking equipment.
35-2011.title: Cooks, Fast Food

35-2012.desc: Prepare and cook large quantities of food for institutions, such as schools, hospitals, or cafeterias.
35-2012.ex: Camp Cook, Galley Cook, Mess Cook, School Cook
35-2012.title: Cooks, Institution and Cafeteria

35-2013.desc: Prepare meals in private homes. Includes personal chefs.
35-2013.title: Cooks, Private Household

35-2014.desc: Prepare, season, and cook dishes such as soups, meats, vegetables, or desserts in restaurants. May order supplies, keep records and accounts, price items on menu, or plan menu.
35-2014.title: Cooks, Restaurant

35-2015.desc: Prepare and cook to order a variety of foods that require only a short preparation time. May take orders from customers and serve patrons at counters or tables.
35-2015.title: Cooks, Short Order

35-2019.ex: Falafel Cart Cook, Fraternity House Cook
35-2019.title: Cooks, All Other

35-2021.desc: Perform a variety of food preparation duties other than cooking, such as preparing cold foods and shellfish, slicing meat, and brewing coffee or tea.
35-2021.ex: Fruit and Vegetable Parer, Salad Maker, Sandwich Maker
35-2021.title: Food Preparation Workers

35-3011.desc: Mix and serve drinks to patrons, directly or through waitstaff.
35-3011.title: Bartenders

35-3023.desc: Perform duties such as taking orders and serving food and beverages. Serve customers at counter or from a steam table. May take payment. May prepare food and beverages. Counter attendants who also wait tables are included in "Waiters and Waitresses" (35-3031),
35-3023.ex: Barista, Cafeteria Server, Ice Cream Server, Mess Attendant, Snack Bar Attendant
35-3023.title: Fast Food and Counter Workers

35-3031.desc: Take orders and serve food and beverages to patrons at tables in dining establishment.
35-3031.ex: Cocktail Server, Dining Car Server, Wine Steward
35-3031.title: Waiters and Waitresses

35-3041.desc: Serve food to individuals outside of a restaurant environment, such as in hotel rooms, hospital rooms, residential care facilities, or cars.
35-3041.ex: Boat Hop, Hospital Food Service Worker, Room Service Food Server
35-3041.title: Food Servers, Nonrestaurant

35-9000._label: Other Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers

35-9010._label: Dining Room and Cafeteria Attendants and Bartender Helpers

35-9011.desc: Facilitate food service. Clean tables; remove dirty dishes; replace soiled table linens; set tables; replenish supply of clean linens, silverware, glassware, and dishes; supply service bar with food; and serve items such as water, condiments, and coffee to patrons.
35-9011.title: Dining Room and Cafeteria Attendants and Bartender Helpers

35-9021.desc: Clean dishes, kitchen, food preparation equipment, or utensils.
35-9021.title: Dishwashers

35-9030._label: Hosts and Hostesses, Restaurant, Lounge, and Coffee Shop

35-9031.desc: Welcome patrons, seat them at tables or in lounge, and help ensure quality of facilities and service.
35-9031.title: Hosts and Hostesses, Restaurant, Lounge, and Coffee Shop

35-9090._label: Miscellaneous Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers

35-9099.desc: All food preparation and serving related workers not listed separately.
35-9099.title: Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers, All Other

37-0000._label: Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Occupations

37-1000._label: Supervisors of Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Workers

37-1010._label: First-Line Supervisors of Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Workers

37-1011.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate work activities of cleaning personnel in hotels, hospitals, offices, and other establishments.
37-1011.ex: Building Cleaning Supervisor, Cleaning Staff Supervisor, Custodial Supervisor
37-1011.title: First-Line Supervisors of Housekeeping and Janitorial Workers

37-1012.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in landscaping or groundskeeping activities.
