49-9021.title: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers

49-9031.desc: Repair, adjust, or install all types of electric or gas household appliances, such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, and ovens.
49-9031.ex: Vacuum Cleaner Repairer, Washing Machine Installer, Window Air Conditioner Installer
49-9031.title: Home Appliance Repairers

49-9040._label: Industrial Machinery Installation, Repair, and Maintenance Workers

49-9041.desc: Repair, install, adjust, or maintain industrial production and processing machinery or refinery and pipeline distribution systems. May also install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to plans.
49-9041.ex: Boilerhouse Mechanic, Foundry Equipment Mechanic, Hydroelectric Machinery Mechanic
49-9041.title: Industrial Machinery Mechanics

49-9043.desc: Lubricate machinery, change parts, or perform other routine machinery maintenance.
49-9043.title: Maintenance Workers, Machinery

49-9044.desc: Install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to layout plans, blueprints, or other drawings.
49-9044.title: Millwrights

49-9045.desc: Build or repair equipment such as furnaces, kilns, cupolas, boilers, converters, ladles, soaking pits, and ovens, using refractory materials.
49-9045.title: Refractory Materials Repairers, Except Brickmasons

49-9051.desc: Install or repair cables or wires used in electrical power or distribution systems. May erect poles and light or heavy duty transmission towers.
49-9051.ex: Electric Powerline Examiner, Electric Utility Lineworker, Electrical High Tension Tester, Electrical Lineworker
49-9051.title: Electrical Power-Line Installers and Repairers

49-9052.desc: Install and repair telecommunications cable, including fiber optics.
49-9052.ex: Cable Television Installer, FIOS Line Installer, Telephone Cable Splicer
49-9052.title: Telecommunications Line Installers and Repairers

49-9061.desc: Repair and adjust cameras and photographic equipment, including commercial video and motion picture camera equipment.
49-9061.ex: Aircraft Photographic Equipment Repairer, Camera Repairer, Photographic Equipment Technician
49-9061.title: Camera and Photographic Equipment Repairers

49-9062.desc: Test, adjust, or repair biomedical or electromedical equipment.
49-9062.ex: Biomedical Equipment Technician, Radiology Equipment Servicer, Surgical Instrument Mechanic
49-9062.title: Medical Equipment Repairers

49-9063.desc: Repair percussion, stringed, reed, or wind instruments. May specialize in one area, such as piano tuning. Excludes "Audiovisual Equipment Installers and Repairers"" (49-2097) who repair electrical and electronic musical instrument
49-9063.ex: Brass and Wind Instrument Repairer, Piano Tuner, Violin Repairer
49-9063.title: Musical Instrument Repairers and Tuners

49-9064.desc: Repair, clean, and adjust mechanisms of timing instruments, such as watches and clocks. Includes watchmakers, watch technicians, and mechanical timepiece repairers. Excludes ""Timing Device Assemblers and Adjusters" (51-2061
49-9064.ex: Antique Clock Repairer, Clock Repair Technician, Horologist
49-9064.title: Watch and Clock Repairers

49-9069.desc: All precision instrument and equipment repairers not listed separately.
49-9069.title: Precision Instrument and Equipment Repairers, All Other

49-9071.desc: Perform work involving the skills of two or more maintenance or craft occupations to keep machines, mechanical equipment, or the structure of a building in repair. Duties may involve pipe fitting; HVAC maintenance; insulating; welding; machining; carpentry; repairing electrical or mechanical equipment; installing, aligning, and balancing new equipment; and repairing buildings, floors, or stairs.
49-9071.ex: Building Maintenance Mechanic, Facilities Maintenance Worker, General Maintenance Worker
49-9071.title: Maintenance and Repair Workers, General

49-9081.desc: Inspect, diagnose, adjust, or repair wind turbines. Perform maintenance on wind turbine equipment including resolving electrical, mechanical, and hydraulic malfunctions.
49-9081.ex: Wind Energy Technician, Wind Turbine Mechanic
49-9081.title: Wind Turbine Service Technicians

49-9090._label: Miscellaneous Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers

49-9091.desc: Install, service, adjust, or repair coin, vending, or amusement machines including video games, juke boxes, pinball machines, or slot machines.
49-9091.ex: Arcade Games Mechanic, Parking Meter Collector, Slot Machine Mechanic, Vending Machine Filler
49-9091.title: Coin, Vending, and Amusement Machine Servicers and Repairers

49-9092.desc: Work below surface of water, using surface-supplied air or scuba equipment to inspect, repair, remove, or install equipment and structures. May use a variety of power and hand tools, such as drills, sledgehammers, torches, and welding equipment. May conduct tests or experiments, rig explosives, or photograph structures or marine life.
49-9092.ex: Marine Diver, Salvage Diver, Scuba Diver, Underwater Welder
49-9092.title: Commercial Divers

49-9094.desc: Repair and open locks, make keys, change locks and safe combinations, and install and repair safes.
49-9094.ex: Key Maker, Safe and Vault Installer, Safe and Vault Mechanic
49-9094.title: Locksmiths and Safe Repairers

49-9095.desc: Move or install mobile homes or prefabricated buildings.
49-9095.ex: Housetrailer Servicer, Mobile Home Mechanic, Mobile Home Servicer
49-9095.title: Manufactured Building and Mobile Home Installers

49-9096.desc: Set up or repair rigging for construction projects, manufacturing plants, logging yards, ships and shipyards, or for the entertainment industry.
49-9096.ex: Acrobatic Rigger, Crane Rigger, Yard Rigger
49-9096.title: Riggers

49-9097.desc: Install, inspect, test, maintain, or repair electric gate crossings, signals, signal equipment, track switches, section lines, or intercommunications systems within a railroad system.
49-9097.ex: Light Rail Signal Technician, Rail Signal Mechanic, Third Rail Installer
49-9097.title: Signal and Track Switch Repairers

49-9098.desc: Help installation, maintenance, and repair workers in maintenance, parts replacement, and repair of vehicles, industrial machinery, and electrical and electronic equipment. Perform duties such as furnishing tools, materials, and supplies to other workers; cleaning work area, machines, and tools; and holding materials or tools for other workers.
49-9098.ex: Automobile Body Repairer Helper, Locksmith Helper, Motorboat Mechanic Helper
49-9098.title: Helpers--Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers

49-9099.desc: All installation, maintenance, and repair workers not listed separately.
49-9099.ex: Bowling Alley Mechanic, Fabric Awning Repairer, Fire Extinguisher Installer, Gasoline Pump Installer, Gunsmith, Parachute Repairer, Sail Repairer
49-9099.title: Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers, All Other

51-1010._label: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers

51-1011.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of production and operating workers, such as inspectors, precision workers, machine setters and operators, assemblers, fabricators, and plant and system operators.
51-1011.ex: Assembly Line Supervisor, Machinist Supervisor, Printing Worker Supervisor
51-1011.title: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers

51-2010._label: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers

51-2011.desc: Assemble, fit, fasten, and install parts of airplanes, space vehicles, or missiles, such as tails, wings, fuselage, bulkheads, stabilizers, landing gear, rigging and control equipment, or heating and ventilating systems.
51-2011.ex: Aircraft De-Icer Installer, Aircraft Fuselage Framer, Aircraft Riveter
51-2011.title: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers

51-2021.desc: Wind wire coils used in electrical components, such as resistors and transformers, and in electrical equipment and instruments, such as field cores, bobbins, armature cores, electrical motors, generators, and control equipment.
51-2021.ex: Coil Builder, Motor Winder, Wire Coiler
51-2021.title: Coil Winders, Tapers, and Finishers

51-2022.desc: Assemble or modify electrical or electronic equipment, such as computers, test equipment telemetering systems, electric motors, and batteries.
51-2022.ex: Anode Builder, Battery Builder, Circuit Board Assembler, Electric Motor Controls Assembler
51-2022.title: Electrical and Electronic Equipment Assemblers

51-2023.desc: Assemble or modify electromechanical equipment or devices, such as servomechanisms, gyros, dynamometers, magnetic drums, tape drives, brakes, control linkage, actuators, and appliances.
51-2023.ex: Programmable Logic Controller Assembler, Synchronous Motor Assembler, Vacuum Cleaner Assembler, Vending Machine Assembler
51-2023.title: Electromechanical Equipment Assemblers

51-2031.desc: Construct, assemble, or rebuild machines, such as engines, turbines, and similar equipment used in such industries as construction, extraction, textiles, and paper manufacturing.
51-2031.ex: Gas Turbine Assembler, Machine Builder, Steam Turbine Assembler
51-2031.title: Engine and Other Machine Assemblers

51-2041.desc: Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products. Shipfitters are included in "Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic" (51-4192).
51-2041.ex: Mill Beam Fitter, Protector Plate Attacher
51-2041.title: Structural Metal Fabricators and Fitters

51-2051.desc: Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.
51-2051.ex: Fiberglass Boat Builder, Fiberglass Ski Maker
51-2051.title: Fiberglass Laminators and Fabricators

51-2061.desc: Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components. Watchmakers are included in "Watch and Clock Repairers" (49-9064).
51-2061.ex: Digital Watch Assembler, Electrical Timing Device Adjuster, Marine Chronometer Assembler
51-2061.title: Timing Device Assemblers and Adjusters

51-2092.desc: Work as part of a team having responsibility for assembling an entire product or component of a product. Team assemblers can perform all tasks conducted by the team in the assembly process and rotate through all or most of them, rather than being assigned to a specific task on a permanent basis. May participate in making management decisions affecting the work. Includes team leaders who work as part of the team. Assemblers who continuously perform the same task are classified elsewhere in 51-2000.
51-2092.ex: Lead Team Assembler, Team Assembly Line Machine Operator, Team Automobile Assembler
51-2092.title: Team Assemblers

51-2099.desc: All assemblers and fabricators not listed separately.
51-2099.ex: Air Bag Builder, Crate Builder, Doll Maker
51-2099.title: Assemblers and Fabricators, All Other

51-3011.desc: Mix and bake ingredients to produce breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, pies, pastries, or other baked goods. Pastry chefs in restaurants and hotels are included with "Chefs and Head Cooks" (35-1011).
51-3011.ex: Bagel Maker, Bread Baker, Pastry Finisher
51-3011.title: Bakers

51-3020._label: Butchers and Other Meat, Poultry, and Fish Processing Workers

51-3021.desc: Cut, trim, or prepare consumer-sized portions of meat for use or sale in retail establishments.
51-3021.ex: Butcher Apprentice, Kosher Butcher, Meat Carver, Meat Counter Worker
51-3021.title: Butchers and Meat Cutters

51-3022.desc: Use hands or hand tools to perform routine cutting and trimming of meat, poultry, and seafood.
51-3022.ex: Fish Filleter, Oyster Shucker, Poultry Eviscerator, Shrimp Picker
51-3022.title: Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers

51-3023.desc: Perform nonroutine or precision functions involving the preparation of large portions of meat. Work may include specialized slaughtering tasks, cutting standard or premium cuts of meat for marketing, making sausage, or wrapping meats. Work typically occurs in slaughtering, meat packing, or wholesale establishments.
51-3023.ex: Halal Meat Packer, Poultry Slaughterer, Shochet
51-3023.title: Slaughterers and Meat Packers

51-3091.desc: Operate or tend food or tobacco roasting, baking, or drying equipment, including hearth ovens, kiln driers, roasters, char kilns, and vacuum drying equipment.
51-3091.ex: Coffee Roaster, Fish Smoker, Meat Curer, Smokehouse Worker
51-3091.title: Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders

51-3092.desc: Set up and operate equipment that mixes or blends ingredients used in the manufacturing of food products. Includes candy makers and cheese makers.
51-3092.ex: Frozen Yogurt Maker, Honey Blender, Peanut Butter Maker
51-3092.title: Food Batchmakers

51-3093.desc: Operate or tend cooking equipment, such as steam cooking vats, deep fry cookers, pressure cookers, kettles, and boilers, to prepare food products.
51-3093.ex: Doughnut Machine Operator, Dumpling Machine Operator, Potato Chip Frier
51-3093.title: Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders

51-3099.desc: All food processing workers not listed separately
51-3099.ex: Olive Pitter, Poultry Hanger, Yeast Maker
51-3099.title: Food Processing Workers, All Other

51-4020._label: Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4021.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines to extrude or draw thermoplastic or metal materials into tubes, rods, hoses, wire, bars, or structural shapes.
51-4021.title: Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4022.desc: Set up, operate, or tend forging machines to taper, shape, or form metal or plastic parts.
51-4022.ex: Cold Header Operator, Forging Roll Operator, Spike Machine Operator, Swager Operator
51-4022.title: Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4023.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines to roll steel or plastic forming bends, beads, knurls, rolls, or plate, or to flatten, temper, or reduce gauge of material.
51-4023.ex: Brass Roller, Forming Roll Operator, Plastic Straightening Roll Operator, Steel Roller
51-4023.title: Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4030._label: Machine Tool Cutting Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4031.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines to saw, cut, shear, slit, punch, crimp, notch, bend, or straighten metal or plastic material.
51-4031.ex: Crimping Machine Operator for Metal, Metal Punch Press Operator, Metal Slitter
51-4031.title: Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4032.desc: Set up, operate, or tend drilling machines to drill, bore, ream, mill, or countersink metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4032.ex: Boring Mill Operator for Metal, Drill Press Operator for Metal, Radial Drill Press Operator for Plastic
51-4032.title: Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4033.desc: Set up, operate, or tend grinding and related tools that remove excess material or burrs from surfaces, sharpen edges or corners, or buff, hone, or polish metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4033.ex: Aluminum Polisher, Jewel Bearing Facer, Metal Grinder, Tool Polishing Machine Operator
51-4033.title: Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4034.desc: Set up, operate, or tend lathe and turning machines to turn, bore, thread, form, or face metal or plastic materials, such as wire, rod, or bar stock.
51-4034.ex: Engine Lathe Operator, Gear Cutter, Screw Machine Operator
51-4034.title: Lathe and Turning Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4035.desc: Set up, operate, or tend milling or planing machines to mill, plane, shape, groove, or profile metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4035.ex: Metal Milling Machine Operator, Plastic Thread Milling Machine Setup Operator
51-4035.title: Milling and Planing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4041.desc: Set up and operate a variety of machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments out of metal. Includes precision instrument makers who fabricate, modify, or repair mechanical instruments. May also fabricate and modify parts to make or repair machine tools or maintain industrial machines, applying knowledge of mechanics, mathematics, metal properties, layout, and machining procedures. Machinists who primarily program or operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-4041.ex: Automotive Machinist, Gear Machinist, Production Machinist
51-4041.title: Machinists

51-4050._label: Metal Furnace Operators, Tenders, Pourers, and Casters

51-4051.desc: Operate or tend furnaces, such as gas, oil, coal, electric-arc or electric induction, open-hearth, or oxygen furnaces, to melt and refine metal before casting or to produce specified types of steel.
51-4051.ex: Electric Arc Furnace Operator, Smelter Operator
51-4051.title: Metal-Refining Furnace Operators and Tenders

51-4052.desc: Operate hand-controlled mechanisms to pour and regulate the flow of molten metal into molds to produce castings or ingots.
51-4052.ex: Ingot Caster, Molten Iron Pourer, Steel Pourer
51-4052.title: Pourers and Casters, Metal

51-4060._label: Model Makers and Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic

51-4061.desc: Set up and operate machines, such as lathes, milling and engraving machines, and jig borers to make working models of metal or plastic objects. Includes template makers.
51-4061.ex: Metal Mockup Maker, Plastic Jig and Fixture Builder
51-4061.title: Model Makers, Metal and Plastic

51-4062.desc: Lay out, machine, fit, and assemble castings and parts to metal or plastic foundry patterns, core boxes, or match plates.
51-4062.title: Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic

51-4070._label: Molders and Molding Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4071.desc: Make or form wax or sand cores or molds used in the production of metal castings in foundries.
51-4071.ex: Airset Caster, Green Sand Molder, Wax Pattern Coater
51-4071.title: Foundry Mold and Coremakers

51-4072.desc: Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.
51-4072.ex: Aluminum Molding Machine Operator, Blow Mold Operator, Plastic Cup Fabricating Machine Operator
51-4072.title: Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4080._label: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4081.desc: Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.
51-4081.ex: Combination Machine Tool Operator, Multi-operation Forming Machine Setter
51-4081.title: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4111.desc: Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists' hand tools.
51-4111.ex: Jig Bore Tool Maker, Metal Die Finisher, Metal Gauge Maker
51-4111.title: Tool and Die Makers

51-4121.desc: Use hand-welding, flame-cutting, hand-soldering, or brazing equipment to weld or join metal components or to fill holes, indentations, or seams of fabricated metal products.
51-4121.ex: Arc Welder, Cutting Torch Operator, Pipe Welder, Silver Solderer
51-4121.title: Welders, Cutters, Solderers, and Brazers

51-4122.desc: Set up, operate, or tend welding, soldering, or brazing machines or robots that weld, braze, solder, or heat treat metal products, components, or assemblies. Includes workers who operate laser cutters or laser-beam machines.
51-4122.ex: Electron Beam Welder Setter, Ultrasonic Welding Machine Operator
51-4122.title: Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-4190._label: Miscellaneous Metal Workers and Plastic Workers

51-4191.desc: Set up, operate, or tend heating equipment, such as heat-treating furnaces, flame-hardening machines, induction machines, soaking pits, or vacuum equipment to temper, harden, anneal, or heat treat metal or plastic objects.
51-4191.ex: Annealing Furnace Operator, Induction Machine Setter, Wire Temperer
51-4191.title: Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4192.desc: Lay out reference points and dimensions on metal or plastic stock or workpieces, such as sheets, plates, tubes, structural shapes, castings, or machine parts, for further processing. Includes shipfitters.
51-4192.title: Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic

51-4193.desc: Set up, operate, or tend plating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces. Typically, the product being coated is immersed in molten metal or an electrolytic solution.
51-4193.title: Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

51-4194.desc: Perform precision smoothing, sharpening, polishing, or grinding of metal objects.
51-4194.title: Tool Grinders, Filers, and Sharpeners

51-4199.desc: All metal workers and plastic workers not listed separately.
51-4199.ex: Electrical Discharge Machine Setup Operator, Metal Rivet Machine Operator, Tin Recovery Worker
51-4199.title: Metal Workers and Plastic Workers, All Other

51-5111.desc: Format and proof text and images submitted by designers and clients into finished pages that can be printed. Includes digital and photo typesetting. May produce printing plates.
51-5111.ex: Digital Proofing and Platemaker, Photoengraver, Plate Mounter
51-5111.title: Prepress Technicians and Workers

51-5112.desc: Set up and operate digital, letterpress, lithographic, flexographic, gravure, or other printing machines. Includes short-run offset printing presses.
51-5112.ex: Gravure Press Operator, Offset Press Operator, Web Press Operator
51-5112.title: Printing Press Operators

51-5113.desc: Bind books and other publications or finish printed products by hand or machine. May set up binding and finishing machines.
51-5113.title: Print Binding and Finishing Workers

51-6011.desc: Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.
51-6011.ex: Laundry Attendant, Laundry Equipment Operator, Laundry Sorter
51-6011.title: Laundry and Dry-Cleaning Workers

51-6020._label: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials

51-6021.desc: Press or shape articles by hand or machine.
51-6021.ex: Clothes Ironer, Pants Presser, Wool Presser
51-6021.title: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials

51-6031.desc: Operate or tend sewing machines to join, reinforce, decorate, or perform related sewing operations in the manufacture of garment or nongarment products.
51-6031.ex: Blind Stitch Machine Operator, Button Sewing Machine Operator, Custom T-Shirt Embroidery Machine Operator
51-6031.title: Sewing Machine Operators

51-6041.desc: Construct, decorate, or repair leather and leather-like products, such as luggage, shoes, and saddles. May use hand tools.
51-6041.ex: Cobbler, Saddle Maker, Shoe Repairer, Shoemaker
51-6041.title: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers

51-6042.desc: Operate or tend a variety of machines to join, decorate, reinforce, or finish shoes and shoe parts.
51-6042.ex: Arch Cushion Press Operator, Lasting Machine Operator, Rasper Machine Operator
51-6042.title: Shoe Machine Operators and Tenders

51-6051.desc: Sew, join, reinforce, or finish, usually with needle and thread, a variety of manufactured items. Includes weavers and stitchers.
51-6051.title: Sewers, Hand

51-6052.desc: Design, make, alter, repair, or fit garments.
51-6052.ex: Alterations Tailor, Coat Maker, Vest Maker
51-6052.title: Tailors, Dressmakers, and Custom Sewers

51-6060._label: Textile Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-6061.desc: Operate or tend machines to bleach, shrink, wash, dye, or finish textiles or synthetic or glass fibers.
51-6061.ex: Cloth Dyer, Rug Dyer, Skein Yarn Dyer
51-6061.title: Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders

51-6062.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut textiles.
51-6062.ex: Canvas Cutter, Industrial Fabric Cutter, Welt Trimming Machine Operator
51-6062.title: Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-6063.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines that knit, loop, weave, or draw in textiles.
51-6063.ex: Crochet Machine Operator, Jacquard Loom Weaver, Looping Machine Operator
51-6063.title: Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-6064.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines that wind or twist textiles; or draw out and combine sliver, such as wool, hemp, or synthetic fibers. Includes slubber machine and drawing frame operators.
51-6064.ex: Rope Machine Setter, Silk Winding Machine Operator
51-6064.title: Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-6090._label: Miscellaneous Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers

51-6091.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form continuous filaments from synthetic materials, such as liquid polymer, rayon, and fiberglass.
51-6091.ex: Fiber Machine Tender, Synthetic Filament Extruder
51-6091.title: Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers

51-6092.desc: Draw and construct sets of precision master fabric patterns or layouts. May also mark and cut fabrics and apparel.
51-6092.ex: Clothing Patternmaker, Embroidery Patternmaker, Fabric Pattern Grader
51-6092.title: Fabric and Apparel Patternmakers

51-6093.desc: Make, repair, or replace upholstery for household furniture or transportation vehicles.
51-6093.title: Upholsterers

51-6099.desc: All textile, apparel, and furnishings workers not listed separately.
51-6099.ex: Apparel Embroidery Digitizer, Feltmaker, Hat Blocking Machine Operator
51-6099.title: Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers, All Other

51-7011.desc: Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products.
51-7011.ex: Cabinet Builder, Marquetry Worker, Wood Furniture Assembler
51-7011.title: Cabinetmakers and Bench Carpenters

51-7021.desc: Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.
51-7021.ex: Furniture Sander, Piano Refinisher, Wood Cabinet Finisher
51-7021.title: Furniture Finishers

51-7031.desc: Construct full-size and scale wooden precision models of products. Includes wood jig builders and loft workers.
51-7031.title: Model Makers, Wood

51-7032.desc: Plan, lay out, and construct wooden unit or sectional patterns used in forming sand molds for castings.
51-7032.title: Patternmakers, Wood

51-7040._label: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-7041.desc: Set up, operate, or tend wood sawing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Includes lead sawyers. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-7041.ex: Buzzsaw Operator, Circle Saw Operator, Rip Saw Operator, Trim Saw Operator
51-7041.title: Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood

51-7042.desc: Set up, operate, or tend woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, and wood nailing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-7042.ex: Wood Dowel Machine Operator, Wood Lathe Operator, Wood Planer
51-7042.title: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing

51-7099.ex: Pole Framer, Wood Carver, Wood Casket Assembler
51-7099.title: Woodworkers, All Other

51-8010._label: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers

51-8011.desc: Operate or control nuclear reactors. Move control rods, start and stop equipment, monitor and adjust controls, and record data in logs. Implement emergency procedures when needed. May respond to abnormalities, determine cause, and recommend corrective action.
51-8011.ex: Nuclear Control Room Operator, Nuclear Reactor Operator, Nuclear Station Operator
51-8011.title: Nuclear Power Reactor Operators

51-8012.desc: Coordinate, regulate, or distribute electricity or steam.
51-8012.ex: Steam Plant Control Room Operator, Substation Operator
51-8012.title: Power Distributors and Dispatchers

51-8013.desc: Control, operate, or maintain machinery to generate electric power. Includes auxiliary equipment operators.
51-8013.title: Power Plant Operators

51-8021.desc: Operate or maintain stationary engines, boilers, or other mechanical equipment to provide utilities for buildings or industrial processes. Operate equipment such as steam engines, generators, motors, turbines, and steam boilers.
51-8021.ex: Boiler Engineer, Boiler Room Operator, Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Mechanic Boiler Operator
51-8021.title: Stationary Engineers and Boiler Operators

51-8030._label: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators

51-8031.desc: Operate or control an entire process or system of machines, often through the use of control boards, to transfer or treat water or wastewater.
51-8031.ex: Liquid Waste Treatment Plant Operator, Sewage Plant Operator
51-8031.title: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators

51-8091.desc: Control or operate entire chemical processes or system of machines.
51-8091.ex: Nitric Acid Plant Operator, Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Machine Operator
51-8091.title: Chemical Plant and System Operators

51-8092.desc: Distribute or process gas for utility companies and others by controlling compressors to maintain specified pressures on main pipelines.
51-8092.title: Gas Plant Operators

51-8093.desc: Operate or control petroleum refining or processing units. May specialize in controlling manifold and pumping systems, gauging or testing oil in storage tanks, or regulating the flow of oil into pipelines.
51-8093.ex: Hydrotreater Operator, Oil Pipeline Operator, Oil Refiner
51-8093.title: Petroleum Pump System Operators, Refinery Operators, and Gaugers

51-8099.desc: All plant and system operators not listed separately.
51-8099.ex: Asphalt Plant Operator, Concrete Batch Plant Operator, Lime Filter Operator
51-8099.title: Plant and System Operators, All Other

51-9010._label: Chemical Processing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9011.desc: Operate or tend equipment to control chemical changes or reactions in the processing of industrial or consumer products. Equipment used includes devulcanizers, steam-jacketed kettles, and reactor vessels.
51-9011.ex: Acid Purification Equipment Operator, Chemical Process Equipment Operator
51-9011.title: Chemical Equipment Operators and Tenders

51-9012.desc: Set up, operate, or tend continuous flow or vat-type equipment; filter presses; shaker screens; centrifuges; condenser tubes; precipitating, fermenting, or evaporating tanks; scrubbing towers; or batch stills. These machines extract, sort, or separate liquids, gases, or solids from other materials to recover a refined product. Includes dairy processing equipment operators.
51-9012.title: Separating, Filtering, Clarifying, Precipitating, and Still Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9020._label: Crushing, Grinding, Polishing, Mixing, and Blending Workers

51-9021.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines to crush, grind, or polish materials, such as coal, glass, grain, stone, food, or rubber.
51-9021.ex: Beveling and Edging Machine Operator, Industrial Coffee Grinder, Marble and Granite Polisher, Pulverizer Operator
51-9021.title: Crushing, Grinding, and Polishing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9022.desc: Grind, sand, or polish, using hand tools or hand-held power tools, a variety of metal, wood, stone, clay, plastic, or glass objects. Includes chippers, buffers, and finishers.
51-9022.ex: Hand Buffer, Hand Sander, Jewelry Polisher, Knife Grinder
51-9022.title: Grinding and Polishing Workers, Hand

51-9023.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines to mix or blend materials, such as chemicals, tobacco, liquids, color pigments, or explosive ingredients.
51-9023.ex: Asphalt Blender, Clay Mixer, Ink Blender
51-9023.title: Mixing and Blending Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9031.desc: Use hand tools or hand-held power tools to cut and trim a variety of manufactured items, such as carpet, fabric, stone, glass, or rubber.
51-9031.title: Cutters and Trimmers, Hand

51-9032.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut or slice materials, such as glass, stone, cork, rubber, tobacco, food, paper, or insulating material.
51-9032.ex: Glass Cutting Machine Operator, Insulation Cutter, Rubber Trimmer
51-9032.title: Cutting and Slicing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9040._label: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9041.desc: Set up, operate, or tend machines, such as glass-forming machines, plodder machines, and tuber machines, to shape and form products such as glassware, food, rubber, soap, brick, tile, clay, wax, tobacco, or cosmetics.
51-9041.ex: Brick Maker, Rubber Extrusion Operator, Sugar Presser
51-9041.title: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9050._label: Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders

51-9051.desc: Operate or tend heating equipment other than basic metal, plastic, or food processing equipment. Includes activities such as annealing glass, drying lumber, curing rubber, removing moisture from materials, or boiling soap.
51-9051.ex: Lime Kiln Operator, Lumber Kiln Operator, Rubber Curer
51-9051.title: Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders

51-9060._label: Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers

51-9061.desc: Inspect, test, sort, sample, or weigh nonagricultural raw materials or processed, machined, fabricated, or assembled parts or products for defects, wear, and deviations from specifications. May use precision measuring instruments and complex test equipment.
51-9061.ex: Machined Parts Quality Inspector, Petroleum Sampler
51-9061.title: Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers

51-9070._label: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers

51-9071.desc: Design, fabricate, adjust, repair, or appraise jewelry, gold, silver, other precious metals, or gems. Includes diamond polishers and gem cutters, and persons who perform precision casting and modeling of molds, casting metal in molds, or setting precious and semiprecious stones for jewelry and related products.
51-9071.title: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers

51-9080._label: Dental and Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians and Medical Appliance Technicians

51-9081.desc: Construct and repair full or partial dentures or dental appliances.
51-9081.ex: Crown and Bridge Technician, Dental Ceramist, Orthodontic Technician
51-9081.title: Dental Laboratory Technicians

51-9082.desc: Construct, maintain, or repair medical supportive devices such as braces, orthotics and prosthetic devices, joints, arch supports, and other surgical and medical appliances.
51-9082.ex: Brace Maker, Manufacturing Orthopedic Technologist, Orthotics Technician, Prosthetics Technician
51-9082.title: Medical Appliance Technicians

51-9083.desc: Cut, grind, and polish eyeglasses, contact lenses, or other precision optical elements. Assemble and mount lenses into frames or process other optical elements. Includes precision lens polishers or grinders, centerer-edgers, and lens mounters.
51-9083.ex: Eyeglass Maker, Lens Grinder, Precision Lens Centerer and Edger
51-9083.title: Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians

51-9110._label: Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders

51-9111.desc: Operate or tend machines to prepare industrial or consumer products for storage or shipment. Includes cannery workers who pack food products.
51-9111.ex: Bottle Capper, Keg Filler, Potato Chip Packaging Machine Operator
51-9111.title: Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders

51-9123.desc: Paint, coat, or decorate articles, such as furniture, glass, plateware, pottery, jewelry, toys, books, or leather. Excludes "Artists and Related Workers"" (27-1010), "Designers" (27-1020), "Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators" (51-9151), and "Etchers and Engravers" (51-9194
51-9123.ex: Ceramic Painter, China Decorator, Sign Painter
51-9123.title: Painting, Coating, and Decorating Workers

51-9124.desc: Set up, operate, or tend spraying or rolling machines to coat or paint any of a wide variety of products, including glassware, cloth, ceramics, metal, plastic, paper, or wood, with lacquer, silver, copper, rubber, varnish, glaze, enamel, oil, or rust-proofing materials. Includes painters of transportation vehicles such as painters in auto body repair facilities.
51-9124.ex: Auto Painter, Electrostatic Paint Operator, Lacquer Spray Booth Operator, Railroad Car Painter
51-9124.title: Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9141.desc: Perform any or all of the following functions in the manufacture of electronic semiconductors: load semiconductor material into furnace; saw formed ingots into segments; load individual segment into crystal growing chamber and monitor controls; locate crystal axis in ingot using x-ray equipment and saw ingots into wafers; and clean, polish, and load wafers into series of special purpose furnaces, chemical baths, and equipment used to form circuitry and change conductive properties.
51-9141.ex: Electronic Semiconductor Processor, Semiconductor Assembler, Wafer Fabricator
51-9141.title: Semiconductor Processing Technicians

51-9150._label: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators

51-9151.desc: Perform work involved in developing and processing photographic images from film or digital media. May perform precision tasks such as editing photographic negatives and prints.
51-9151.ex: Digital Photo Printer, Photo Lab Specialist, Photo Retoucher
51-9151.title: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators

51-9160._label: Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers

51-9161.desc: Operate computer-controlled tools, machines, or robots to machine or process parts, tools, or other work pieces made of metal, plastic, wood, stone, or other materials. May also set up and maintain equipment.
51-9161.ex: Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Machinist, Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Milling Machine Operator, Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Shot Peening Operator, Jig Boring Machine Operator, Welding Robot Operator
51-9161.title: Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators

51-9162.desc: Develop programs to control machining or processing of materials by automatic machine tools, equipment, or systems. May also set up, operate, or maintain equipment.
51-9162.ex: Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Programmer, Numerical Control Programmer, Numerical Tool Programmer
51-9162.title: Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Programmers

51-9191.desc: Operate or tend bonding machines that use adhesives to join items for further processing or to form a completed product. Processes include joining veneer sheets into plywood; gluing paper; or joining rubber and rubberized fabric parts, plastic, simulated leather, or other materials.
51-9191.ex: Glue Line Operator, Glue Reel Operator, Paper Gluing Operator
51-9191.title: Adhesive Bonding Machine Operators and Tenders

51-9192.desc: Operate or tend machines to wash or clean products, such as barrels or kegs, glass items, tin plate, food, pulp, coal, plastic, or rubber, to remove impurities.
51-9192.ex: Acid Dipper, Degreaser Operator, Immersion Metal Cleaner
51-9192.title: Cleaning, Washing, and Metal Pickling Equipment Operators and Tenders

51-9193.desc: Operate or tend equipment such as cooling and freezing units, refrigerators, batch freezers, and freezing tunnels, to cool or freeze products, food, blood plasma, and chemicals.
51-9193.title: Cooling and Freezing Equipment Operators and Tenders

51-9194.desc: Engrave or etch metal, wood, rubber, or other materials. Includes such workers as etcher-circuit processors, pantograph engravers, and silk screen etchers. Photoengravers are included in "Prepress Technicians and Workers" (51-5111).
51-9194.title: Etchers and Engravers

51-9195.desc: Mold, shape, form, cast, or carve products such as food products, figurines, tile, pipes, and candles consisting of clay, glass, plaster, concrete, stone, or combinations of materials.
51-9195.ex: Cigar Roller, Glass Blower, Neon Tube Bender
51-9195.title: Molders, Shapers, and Casters, Except Metal and Plastic

51-9196.desc: Set up, operate, or tend paper goods machines that perform a variety of functions, such as converting, sawing, corrugating, banding, wrapping, boxing, stitching, forming, or sealing paper or paperboard sheets into products.
51-9196.ex: Box Fabricator, Carton Making Machine Operator, Corrugator Operator
51-9196.title: Paper Goods Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

51-9197.ex: Auto Tire Recapper, Retreader, Tire Molder
51-9197.title: Tire Builders

51-9198.desc: Help production workers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include supplying or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Apprentice workers are classified in the appropriate production occupations (51-0000).
51-9198.ex: Blending Tank Helper, Commercial Baker Helper, Welder Helper
51-9198.title: Helpers--Production Workers

51-9199.desc: All production workers not listed separately.
51-9199.title: Production Workers, All Other

53-1000._label: Supervisors of Transportation and Material Moving Workers

53-1040._label: First-Line Supervisors of Transportation and Material Moving Workers

53-1041.desc: Supervise and coordinate the activities of ground crew in the loading, unloading, securing, and staging of aircraft cargo or baggage. May determine the quantity and orientation of cargo and compute aircraft center of gravity. May accompany aircraft as member of flight crew and monitor and handle cargo in flight, and assist and brief passengers on safety and emergency procedures. Includes loadmasters.
53-1041.ex: Air Cargo Ground Crew Supervisor, Air Cargo Ground Operations Supervisor, Airport Ramp Supervisor
53-1041.title: Aircraft Cargo Handling Supervisors

53-1042.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of helpers, laborers, or material movers, hand.
53-1042.ex: Material Handling Crew Supervisor, Warehouse Supervisor
53-1042.title: First-Line Supervisors of Helpers, Laborers, and Material Movers, Hand

53-1043.desc: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of material-moving machine and vehicle operators and helpers.
53-1043.ex: Crane Crew Supervisor, Truck Driver Supervisor
53-1043.title: First-Line Supervisors of Material-Moving Machine and Vehicle Operators

53-1044.desc: Supervise and coordinate activities of passenger attendants. Includes supervisors of "Flight Attendants" (53-2031).
53-1044.ex: Chief Ship Steward, Flight Service Manager
53-1044.title: First-Line Supervisors of Passenger Attendants

53-1049.desc: All first-line supervisors of transportation workers not listed separately.
53-1049.title: First-Line Supervisors of Transportation Workers, All Other

53-2011.desc: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft, usually on scheduled air carrier routes, for the transport of passengers and cargo. Requires Federal Air Transport certificate and rating for specific aircraft type used. Includes regional, national, and international airline pilots and flight instructors of airline pilots.
53-2011.ex: Airline Captain, Airline Pilot In Command, Charter Pilot (Air Transport Pilot Certificate Required), Charter Pilot (Airline)
53-2011.title: Airline Pilots, Copilots, and Flight Engineers

53-2012.desc: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft on nonscheduled air carrier routes, or helicopters. Requires Commercial Pilot certificate. Includes charter pilots with similar certification, and air ambulance and air tour pilots. Excludes "Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians" (17-3024).
53-2012.ex: Aerial Crop Duster, Charter Pilot (Commercial Pilot Certificate Required), Flight Instructor (Commercial Pilots), Helicopter Pilot
53-2012.title: Commercial Pilots

53-2020._label: Air Traffic Controllers and Airfield Operations Specialists

53-2021.desc: Control air traffic on and within vicinity of airport, and movement of air traffic between altitude sectors and control centers, according to established procedures and policies. Authorize, regulate, and control commercial airline flights according to government or company regulations to expedite and ensure flight safety.
53-2021.ex: Air Traffic Control Operator, Control Tower Operator, Enroute Controller
53-2021.title: Air Traffic Controllers

53-2022.desc: Ensure the safe takeoff and landing of commercial and military aircraft. Duties include coordination between air-traffic control and maintenance personnel, dispatching, using airfield landing and navigational aids, implementing airfield safety procedures, monitoring and maintaining flight records, and applying knowledge of weather information.
53-2022.ex: Aviation Operations Specialist, Flight Operations Coordinator
53-2022.title: Airfield Operations Specialists

53-2031.desc: Monitor safety of the aircraft cabin. Provide services to airline passengers, explain safety information, serve food and beverages, and respond to emergency incidents.
53-2031.ex: Airline Flight Attendant, Airplane Flight Attendant
53-2031.title: Flight Attendants

53-3010._label: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians

53-3011.desc: Drive ambulance or assist ambulance driver in transporting sick, injured, or convalescent persons. Assist in lifting patients.
53-3011.title: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians

53-3031.desc: Drive truck or other vehicle over established routes or within an established territory and sell or deliver goods, such as food products, including restaurant take-out items, or pick up or deliver items such as commercial laundry. May also take orders, collect payment, or stock merchandise at point of delivery.
53-3031.ex: Newspaper Delivery Driver, Pizza Delivery Driver, Route Salesperson
53-3031.title: Driver/Sales Workers

53-3032.desc: Drive a tractor-trailer combination or a truck with a capacity of at least 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW). May be required to unload truck. Requires commercial drivers' license. Includes tow truck drivers.
53-3032.ex: Auto Carrier Driver, Cement Truck Driver, Dump Truck Driver, Garbage Truck Driver
53-3032.title: Heavy and Tractor-Trailer Truck Drivers

53-3033.desc: Drive a light vehicle, such as a truck or van, with a capacity of less than 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW), primarily to pick up merchandise or packages from a distribution center and deliver. May load and unload vehicle.
53-3033.ex: Grocery Light Truck Driver, Parcel Truck Driver
53-3033.title: Light Truck Drivers

53-3051.desc: Drive a school bus to transport students. Ensure adherence to safety rules. May assist students in boarding or exiting.
53-3051.ex: School Bus Operator, Special Education Bus Driver
53-3051.title: Bus Drivers, School

53-3052.desc: Drive bus or motor coach, including regular route operations, charters, and private carriage. May assist passengers with baggage. May collect fares or tickets.
53-3052.ex: Motor Coach Bus Driver, Public Transit Bus Driver
53-3052.title: Bus Drivers, Transit and Intercity

53-3053.desc: Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on a planned or scheduled basis. May collect a fare. Includes nonemergency medical transporters and hearse drivers.
53-3053.ex: Airport Shuttle Driver, Courtesy Van Driver, Hotel Shuttle Driver, Nonemergency Medical Transporter
53-3053.title: Shuttle Drivers and Chauffeurs

53-3054.desc: Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on an unplanned basis and charge a fare, usually based on a meter.
53-3054.title: Taxi Drivers

53-3099.desc: All motor vehicle operators not listed separately.
53-3099.ex: Ice-Resurfacing Machine Operators, Motorcycle Deliverer, Street Cleaning Equipment Operator
53-3099.title: Motor Vehicle Operators, All Other

53-4011.desc: Drive electric, diesel-electric, steam, or gas-turbine-electric locomotives to transport passengers or freight. Interpret train orders, electronic or manual signals, and railroad rules and regulations.
53-4011.title: Locomotive Engineers

53-4013.desc: Drive switching or other locomotive or dinkey engines within railroad yard, industrial plant, quarry, construction project, or similar location.
53-4013.title: Rail Yard Engineers, Dinkey Operators, and Hostlers

53-4020._label: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators and Locomotive Firers

53-4022.desc: Operate or monitor railroad track switches or locomotive instruments. May couple or uncouple rolling stock to make up or break up trains. Watch for and relay traffic signals. May inspect couplings, air hoses, journal boxes, and hand brakes. May watch for dragging equipment or obstacles on rights-of-way.
53-4022.ex: Diesel Locomotive Firer, Dinkey Engine Firer, Railway Switch Operator, Switch Coupler, Train Brake Operator
53-4022.title: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators and Locomotive Firers

53-4031.desc: Coordinate activities of switch-engine crew within railroad yard, industrial plant, or similar location. Conductors coordinate activities of train crew on passenger or freight trains. Yardmasters review train schedules and switching orders and coordinate activities of workers engaged in railroad traffic operations, such as the makeup or breakup of trains and yard switching.
53-4031.title: Railroad Conductors and Yardmasters

53-4041.desc: Operate subway or elevated suburban trains with no separate locomotive, or electric-powered streetcar, to transport passengers. May handle fares.
53-4041.ex: Light Rail Transit Operator, Tram Operator, Trolley Car Operator
53-4041.title: Subway and Streetcar Operators

53-4099.desc: All rail transportation workers not listed separately.
53-4099.ex: Railway Equipment Operator, Retarder Operator, Transfer Table Operator
53-4099.title: Rail Transportation Workers, All Other

53-5011.desc: Stand watch to look for obstructions in path of vessel, measure water depth, turn wheel on bridge, or use emergency equipment as directed by captain, mate, or pilot. Break out, rig, overhaul, and store cargo-handling gear, stationary rigging, and running gear. Perform a variety of maintenance tasks to preserve the painted surface of the ship and to maintain line and ship equipment. Must hold government-issued certification and tankerman certification when working aboard liquid-carrying vessels. Includes able seamen and ordinary seamen.
53-5011.title: Sailors and Marine Oilers

53-5020._label: Ship and Boat Captains and Operators

53-5021.desc: Command or supervise operations of ships and water vessels, such as tugboats and ferryboats. Required to hold license issued by U.S. Coast Guard.
53-5021.ex: Barge Captain, First Mate, Harbor Pilot, Port Captain
53-5021.title: Captains, Mates, and Pilots of Water Vessels

53-5022.desc: Operate small motor-driven boats. May assist in navigational activities.
53-5022.ex: Launch Operator, Speedboat Operator, Water Taxi Operator
53-5022.title: Motorboat Operators

53-5031.desc: Supervise and coordinate activities of crew engaged in operating and maintaining engines, boilers, deck machinery, and electrical, sanitary, and refrigeration equipment aboard ship.
53-5031.ex: Barge Engineer, Ferry Engineer, Tugboat Engineer
53-5031.title: Ship Engineers

53-6011.desc: Operate and tend bridges, canal locks, and lighthouses to permit marine passage on inland waterways, near shores, and at danger points in waterway passages. May supervise such operations. Includes drawbridge operators, lock operators, and slip bridge operators.
53-6011.ex: Lighthouse Keeper, Lock and Dam Operator
53-6011.title: Bridge and Lock Tenders

53-6021.desc: Park vehicles or issue tickets for customers in a parking lot or garage. May park or tend vehicles in environments such as a car dealership or rental car facility. May collect fee.
53-6021.title: Parking Attendants

53-6031.desc: Service automobiles, buses, trucks, boats, and other automotive or marine vehicles with fuel, lubricants, and accessories. Collect payment for services and supplies. May lubricate vehicle, change motor oil, refill antifreeze, or replace lights or other accessories, such as windshield wiper blades or fan belts. May repair or replace tires.
53-6031.ex: Gas and Oil Servicer, Gas Pump Attendant, Service Station Attendant
53-6031.title: Automotive and Watercraft Service Attendants

53-6032.desc: Service aircraft with fuel. May de-ice aircraft, refill water and cooling agents, empty sewage tanks, service air and oxygen systems, or clean and polish exterior.
53-6032.ex: Aircraft De-Icer, Aircraft Refueler, Airplane Refueler
53-6032.title: Aircraft Service Attendants

53-6041.desc: Conduct field studies to determine traffic volume, speed, effectiveness of signals, adequacy of lighting, and other factors influencing traffic conditions, under direction of traffic engineer.
53-6041.ex: Highway Traffic Control Technician, Traffic Signal Technician, Transportation Technician
53-6041.title: Traffic Technicians

53-6051.desc: Inspect equipment or goods in connection with the safe transport of cargo or people. Includes rail transportation inspectors, such as freight inspectors, rail inspectors, and other inspectors of transportation vehicles not elsewhere classified.
53-6051.ex: Aircraft Inspector, Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspector, Railroad Car Inspector
53-6051.title: Transportation Inspectors

53-6061.desc: Provide services to ensure the safety of passengers aboard ships, buses, trains, or within the station or terminal. Perform duties such as explaining the use of safety equipment, serving meals or beverages, or answering questions related to travel.
53-6061.title: Passenger Attendants

53-6099.desc: All transportation workers not listed separately.
53-6099.title: Transportation Workers, All Other

53-7011.desc: Control or tend conveyors or conveyor systems that move materials or products to and from stockpiles, processing stations, departments, or vehicles. May control speed and routing of materials or products.
53-7011.ex: Conveyor Belt Operator, Grain Elevator Operator
53-7011.title: Conveyor Operators and Tenders

53-7021.desc: Operate mechanical boom and cable or tower and cable equipment to lift and move materials, machines, or products in many directions.
53-7021.ex: Boom Crane Operator, Cherry Picker Operator, Coal Tower Operator
53-7021.title: Crane and Tower Operators

53-7031.desc: Operate dredge to remove sand, gravel, or other materials in order to excavate and maintain navigable channels in waterways.
53-7031.title: Dredge Operators

53-7041.desc: Operate or tend hoists or winches to lift and pull loads using power-operated cable equipment.
53-7041.title: Hoist and Winch Operators

53-7051.desc: Operate industrial trucks or tractors equipped to move materials around a warehouse, storage yard, factory, construction site, or similar location.
53-7051.title: Industrial Truck and Tractor Operators

53-7061.desc: Wash or otherwise clean vehicles, machinery, and other equipment. Use such materials as water, cleaning agents, brushes, cloths, and hoses.
53-7061.ex: Aircraft Cleaner, Auto Detailer, Car Wash Attendant
53-7061.title: Cleaners of Vehicles and Equipment

53-7062.desc: Manually move freight, stock, luggage, or other materials, or perform other general labor. Includes all manual laborers not elsewhere classified. Excludes "Material Moving Workers" (53-7011 through 53-7199) who use power equipment.
53-7062.title: Laborers and Freight, Stock, and Material Movers, Hand

53-7063.desc: Feed materials into or remove materials from machines or equipment that is automatic or tended by other workers.
53-7063.title: Machine Feeders and Offbearers

53-7064.desc: Pack or package by hand a wide variety of products and materials.
53-7064.ex: Egg Packer, Gift Wrapper, Grocery Store Bagger
53-7064.title: Packers and Packagers, Hand

53-7065.desc: Receive, store, and issue merchandise, materials, equipment, and other items from stockroom, warehouse, or storage yard to fill shelves, racks, tables, or customers' orders. May operate power equipment to fill orders. May mark prices on merchandise and set up sales displays.
53-7065.ex: Night Stocker, Store Stocker, Warehouse Stocker
53-7065.title: Stockers and Order Fillers

53-7071.desc: Operate steam-, gas-, electric motor-, or internal combustion-engine driven compressors. Transmit, compress, or recover gases, such as butane, nitrogen, hydrogen, and natural gas.
53-7071.ex: Butane Compressor Operator, Gas Cylinder Processor, Liquid Natural Gas Plant Operator
53-7071.title: Gas Compressor and Gas Pumping Station Operators

53-7072.desc: Tend, control, or operate power-driven, stationary, or portable pumps and manifold systems to transfer gases, oil, other liquids, slurries, or powdered materials to and from various vessels and processes.
53-7072.title: Pump Operators, Except Wellhead Pumpers

53-7073.desc: Operate power pumps and auxiliary equipment to produce flow of oil or gas from wells in oil field.
53-7073.title: Wellhead Pumpers

53-7081.desc: Collect and dump refuse or recyclable materials from containers into truck. May drive truck.
53-7081.ex: Garbage Collector, Recyclable Materials Collector, Trash Collector
53-7081.title: Refuse and Recyclable Material Collectors

53-7120._label: Tank Car, Truck, and Ship Loaders

53-7121.desc: Load and unload chemicals and bulk solids, such as coal, sand, and grain, into or from tank cars, trucks, or ships, using material moving equipment. May perform a variety of other tasks relating to shipment of products. May gauge or sample shipping tanks and test them for leaks.
53-7121.ex: Barge Loader, Rail Car Loader, Ship Unloader
53-7121.title: Tank Car, Truck, and Ship Loaders

53-7199.desc: All material moving workers not listed separately.
53-7199.ex: Bulldozer Operator, Freight Elevator Operator, Shovel Operator
53-7199.title: Material Moving Workers, All Other

55-1000._label: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders

55-1010._label: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders

55-1011.desc: Perform and direct in-flight duties to ensure the successful completion of combat, reconnaissance, transport, and search and rescue missions. Duties include operating aircraft communications and radar equipment, such as establishing satellite linkages and jamming enemy communications capabilities; operating aircraft weapons and defensive systems; conducting preflight, in-flight, and postflight inspections of onboard equipment; and directing cargo and personnel drops.
55-1011.ex: Air Battle Manager, Airdrop Systems Technician, Special Project Airborne Electronics Evaluator
55-1011.title: Air Crew Officers

55-1012.desc: Plan and direct the operation and maintenance of catapults, arresting gear, and associated mechanical, hydraulic, and control systems involved primarily in aircraft carrier takeoff and landing operations. Duties include supervision of readiness and safety of arresting gear, launching equipment, barricades, and visual landing aid systems; planning and coordinating the design, development, and testing of launch and recovery systems; preparing specifications for catapult and arresting gear installations; evaluating design proposals; determining handling equipment needed for new aircraft; preparing technical data and instructions for operation of landing aids; and training personnel in carrier takeoff and landing procedures.
55-1012.ex: Catapult And Arresting Gear Officer, Flight Deck Officer, Landing Signal Officer
55-1012.title: Aircraft Launch and Recovery Officers

55-1013.desc: Direct the operation of tanks, light armor, and amphibious assault vehicle units during combat situations on land or in aquatic environments. Duties include directing crew members in the operation of targeting and firing systems; coordinating the operation of advanced onboard communications and navigation equipment; directing the transport of personnel and equipment during combat; formulating and implementing battle plans, including the tactical employment of armored vehicle units; and coordinating with infantry, artillery, and air support units.
55-1013.ex: Assault Amphibious Vehicle (AAV) Officer, Cavalry Officer, Tank Officer
55-1013.title: Armored Assault Vehicle Officers

55-1014.desc: Manage personnel and weapons operations to destroy enemy positions, aircraft, and vessels. Duties include planning, targeting, and coordinating the tactical deployment of field artillery and air defense artillery missile systems units; directing the establishment and operation of fire control communications systems; targeting and launching intercontinental ballistic missiles; directing the storage and handling of nuclear munitions and components; overseeing security of weapons storage and launch facilities; and managing maintenance of weapons systems.
55-1014.ex: Air Defense Artillery Officer, Naval Surface Fire Support Planner, Targeting Acquisition Officer
55-1014.title: Artillery and Missile Officers

55-1015.desc: Manage the operation of communications, detection, and weapons systems essential for controlling air, ground, and naval operations. Duties include managing critical communication links between air, naval, and ground forces; formulating and implementing emergency plans for natural and wartime disasters; coordinating emergency response teams and agencies; evaluating command center information and need for high-level military and government reporting; managing the operation of surveillance and detection systems; providing technical information and advice on capabilities and operational readiness; and directing operation of weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.
55-1015.ex: Combat Information Center Officer, Command And Control Officer, Command And Control Systems Integrator
55-1015.title: Command and Control Center Officers

55-1016.desc: Direct, train, and lead infantry units in ground combat operations. Duties include directing deployment of infantry weapons, vehicles, and equipment; directing location, construction, and camouflage of infantry positions and equipment; managing field communications operations; coordinating with armor, artillery, and air support units; performing strategic and tactical planning, including battle plan development; and leading basic reconnaissance operations.
55-1016.title: Infantry Officers

55-1017.desc: Lead elite teams that implement unconventional operations by air, land, or sea during combat or peacetime. These activities include offensive raids, demolitions, reconnaissance, search and rescue, and counterterrorism. In addition to their combat training, special forces officers often have specialized training in swimming, diving, parachuting, survival, emergency medicine, and foreign languages. Duties include directing advanced reconnaissance operations and evaluating intelligence information; recruiting, training, and equipping friendly forces; leading raids and invasions on enemy territories; training personnel to implement individual missions and contingency plans; performing strategic and tactical planning for politically sensitive missions; and operating sophisticated communications equipment.
55-1017.title: Special Forces Officers

55-1019.desc: All military officer special and tactical operations leaders not listed separately.
55-1019.ex: Chemical, Biological, Radiological, And Nuclear (CBRN) Officer, Joint Strategic Plans And Policy Officer, Special Technical Operations Officer
55-1019.title: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders, All Other

55-2011.desc: Supervise and coordinate the activities of air crew members. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.
55-2011.ex: Airborne Mission Systems Superintendent, In-Flight Refueling Manager
55-2011.title: First-Line Supervisors of Air Crew Members

55-2012.desc: Supervise and coordinate the activities of weapons specialists/crew members. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.
55-2012.ex: Armor Senior Sergeant, Field Artillery Senior Sergeant, Infantry Unit Leader
55-2012.title: First-Line Supervisors of Weapons Specialists/Crew Members

55-2013.desc: Supervise and coordinate the activities of all other tactical operations specialists not classified separately above. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.
55-2013.ex: Command Post Superintendent, Intelligence Chief, Surface Ship USW Supervisor
55-2013.title: First-Line Supervisors of All Other Tactical Operations Specialists

55-3000._label: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members

55-3010._label: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members

55-3011.desc: Perform in-flight duties to ensure the successful completion of combat, reconnaissance, transport, and search and rescue missions. Duties include operating aircraft communications and detection equipment, including establishing satellite linkages and jamming enemy communications capabilities; conducting preflight, in-flight, and postflight inspections of onboard equipment; operating and maintaining aircraft weapons and defensive systems; operating and maintaining aircraft in-flight refueling systems; executing aircraft safety and emergency procedures; computing and verifying passenger, cargo, fuel, and emergency and special equipment weight and balance data; and conducting cargo and personnel drops.
55-3011.ex: Airborne And Air Delivery Specialist, Aviation Electronic Warfare Operator, In-Flight Refueling Craftsman
55-3011.title: Air Crew Members

55-3012.desc: Operate and maintain catapults, arresting gear, and associated mechanical, hydraulic, and control systems involved primarily in aircraft carrier takeoff and landing operations. Duties include installing and maintaining visual landing aids; testing and maintaining launch and recovery equipment using electric and mechanical test equipment and hand tools; activating airfield arresting systems, such as crash barriers and cables, during emergency landing situations; directing aircraft launch and recovery operations using hand or light signals; and maintaining logs of airplane launches, recoveries, and equipment maintenance.
55-3012.ex: Aircraft Launch And Recovery Equipment Maintenance Technician, C-13 Catapult Operator, Expeditionary Airfield Systems Technician
55-3012.title: Aircraft Launch and Recovery Specialists

55-3013.desc: Operate tanks, light armor, and amphibious assault vehicles during combat situations on land or in aquatic environments. Duties include driving armored vehicles that require specialized training; operating and maintaining targeting and firing systems; operating and maintaining advanced onboard communications and navigation equipment; transporting personnel and equipment in a combat environment; and operating and maintaining auxiliary weapons, including machine guns and grenade launchers.
55-3013.ex: Assault Boat Coxswain, Bradley Linebacker Crewmember, M1A1 Tank Crewman
55-3013.title: Armored Assault Vehicle Crew Members

55-3014.desc: Target, fire, and maintain weapons used to destroy enemy positions, aircraft, and vessels. Field artillery crew members predominantly use guns, cannons, and howitzers in ground combat operations, while air defense artillery crew members predominantly use missiles and rockets. Naval artillery crew members predominantly use torpedoes and missiles launched from a ship or submarine. Duties include testing, inspecting, and storing ammunition, missiles, and torpedoes; conducting preventive and routine maintenance on weapons and related equipment; establishing and maintaining radio and wire communications; and operating weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.
55-3014.ex: Air And Missile Defense (AMD) Crewmember, Field Artillery Fire Control Man, Gunner's Mate
55-3014.title: Artillery and Missile Crew Members

55-3015.desc: Operate and monitor communications, detection, and weapons systems essential for controlling air, ground, and naval operations. Duties include maintaining and relaying critical communications between air, naval, and ground forces; implementing emergency plans for natural and wartime disasters; relaying command center information to high-level military and government decisionmakers; monitoring surveillance and detection systems, such as air defense; interpreting and evaluating tactical situations and making recommendations to superiors; and operating weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.
55-3015.ex: Air Defense Command, Control, Communications, Computers And Intelligence Tactical Operations Center, C2 Tactical Analysis Technician, Command Post Craftsman
55-3015.title: Command and Control Center Specialists

55-3016.desc: Operate weapons and equipment in ground combat operations. Duties include operating and maintaining weapons, such as rifles, machine guns, mortars, and hand grenades; locating, constructing, and camouflaging infantry positions and equipment; evaluating terrain and recording topographical information; operating and maintaining field communications equipment; assessing need for and directing supporting fire; placing explosives and performing minesweeping activities on land; and participating in basic reconnaissance operations.
55-3016.title: Infantry

55-3018.desc: Implement unconventional operations by air, land, or sea during combat or peacetime as members of elite teams. These activities include offensive raids, demolitions, reconnaissance, search and rescue, and counterterrorism. In addition to their combat training, special forces members often have specialized training in swimming, diving, parachuting, survival, emergency medicine, and foreign languages. Duties include conducting advanced reconnaissance operations and collecting intelligence information; recruiting, training, and equipping friendly forces; conducting raids and invasions on enemy territories; laying and detonating explosives for demolition targets; locating, identifying, defusing, and disposing of ordnance; and operating and maintaining sophisticated communications equipment.
55-3018.ex: Combatant Swimmer (SEAL), Pararescue Craftsman, Special Forces Weapons Sergeant
55-3018.title: Special Forces

55-3019.desc: All military enlisted tactical operations and air/weapons specialists and crewmembers not listed separately.
55-3019.ex: Electronic Warfare Specialist, Landing Support Specialist, Psychological Operations Specialist
55-3019.title: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members, All Other
